Subject: [InDE-devel] internationalization & ctags
Message-ID: <1109802540.1541.16.camel@jogix.sojox>

Hi Jannis.

I just read the internationalization is growing in the new fox
development tree..... seems like we can start to look for translators
after our first release ;)

Although i haven't had the nerves to code last two days i used some time
today to read a bit and think some things over.
Have you yet supported ctags for the editor widget?

I have the idea to implement a class browser based on ctags. For we are
using ctags for syntax highlighting, it should be only minimal work to
add a class browser based on the same data. And BTW, without knowing
what you are actually coding, we should think about a timer or a certain
event to actualize the ctags file for project data.

Also i thought about displaying multiple projects in InDE. After
completing the projehct browser, i will have a look at this. I think it
is a very easy enhancement but with great benefit.

sincerly
	Jochen

Do you remember we talked about a mail from me that seemed not to arrive 
to the mailinglist? I wrote
something about ctags there but that mail is gone, so lets start this 
topic here.

We can use ctags for autocompletion and the class browser. For 
syntaxhighlighting this won't be too
interesting but perhaps we could find out class names that appear in the 
project and highlight them.

I haven't coded the last days, too but I looked at a program called 
"ReZound". That's an audio editor
written in FOX. After having seen their code I could imange to implement 
some backend classes for
tasks like periodically updating the project's ctags file and so on. The 
goal is to take some code out
of MainWindow since it would grow too large otherwise.

We could probably divide the code maintainance. If I'm responsible for 
the editor widget, syntaxhighlighting
and so on it would only be logical to do the class browser. Whereas you 
were responsible for
project management and, lets say, the build instructions. Just an idea, 
yet I don't know if you agree.

>completing the projehct browser, i will have a look at this. I think it
>is a very easy enhancement but with great benefit.

At the moment this might be a little complicated due to the central 
project settings structure in MainWindow.
Maybe we will have to rewrite it in order to store them in a list. I 
think we should still wait with it.

Regards,
Jannis (wo is still thinking about structure optimizations all the time)

From jochen at cornmania.de  Thu Mar  3 14:30:10 2005
From: jochen at cornmania.de (Jochen Rassler)
Date: Thu, 03 Mar 2005 14:30:10 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] garbage collector?
Message-ID: <1109856610.1557.32.camel@jogix.sojox>

Hi Jannis.

I have a problem and don't know why :(

I am working on the project browser. This is a class, which includes a
FXTreeList.

The FXTreeList is initialized in the constructor of ProjectBrowser and
deleted in the destructor.

The FXTreeItems are build dynamically in several functions.

If i close InDE, i get a segmentation fault, while deleting
projectBrowser in MainWindow's destructor. If i comment that line out,
everythings seems fine (?). Debugging into ProjectBrowser's destructor
tells me, that everything works fine there.

Why do i get the segmentation fault while deleting projectBrowser?

What about the FXTreeItems? As long as they are part of FXTreeList, they
are deleted with FXTreeList like in control of a garbage collector?

Any hints?

regards
	Jochen

Ha Jannis.

Am Donnerstag, den 03.03.2005, 14:49 +0100 schrieb Jannis Pohlmann:
> I just saw an article in the FOX Wiki - 
> http://fox-toolkit.net/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?Cookbook/Iterating_Over_Entries_In_FXSettings 
> -
> which could be interesting. This could probably replace all the 
> "onUpdSetting..." and "onCmdSetting..."
> functions and our settings structs as well. Just a few methods for 
> reading, writing the settings and
> some for handling certain option changes would remain. Maybe this could 
> spare a lot of code and make
> it easier to read.

The question is, do we need iterating?
But reading only those sections at those places, where we need it, would
save memory, keep the code cleaner, minimize sources for bugs.
Maybe something like FXbool GUIdirty may be used to indicate, that
several widgets should reread the settings and mark themself dirty.

BTW, have you already implemented something like the new file menu
command or open or any of these operations?
I have actually build up the infrastructure for the new files to test
the project browser.... but if you've done anything on this, we should
discuss this beforge merging.

CU
Jochen

From devel at sten-net.de  Fri Mar  4 12:42:11 2005

Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 12:42:11 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] internationalization & ctags
In-Reply-To: <1109865977.1557.63.camel@jogix.sojox>
References: <1109802540.1541.16.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <422707F0.9050009@sten-net.de> <1109856121.1557.21.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <422715DA.6040506@sten-net.de> <1109865977.1557.63.camel@jogix.sojox>
Message-ID: <42284993.2030901@sten-net.de>

Jochen Rassler schrieb:

>Ha Jannis.
>
>Am Donnerstag, den 03.03.2005, 14:49 +0100 schrieb Jannis Pohlmann:
>  
>
>>I just saw an article in the FOX Wiki - 
>>http://fox-toolkit.net/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?Cookbook/Iterating_Over_Entries_In_FXSettings 
>>-
>>which could be interesting. This could probably replace all the 
>>"onUpdSetting..." and "onCmdSetting..."
>>functions and our settings structs as well. Just a few methods for 
>>reading, writing the settings and
>>some for handling certain option changes would remain. Maybe this could 
>>spare a lot of code and make
>>it easier to read.
>>    
>>
>
>The question is, do we need iterating?
>But reading only those sections at those places, where we need it, would
>save memory, keep the code cleaner, minimize sources for bugs.
>Maybe something like FXbool GUIdirty may be used to indicate, that
>several widgets should reread the settings and mark themself dirty.
>  
>
Probably we won't need iterating. At the moment, I'm testing a way to 
read all settings from a
file placed in ~/.InDE/, replacing the options not found in that file by 
default values.
That seems not to be too difficult. Reading settings partly doesn't make 
sense since FXSettings,
FXStringDict and FXDict don't need much memory space. The basic way is this:

MainWindow constructor:

    settings = new FXSettings;
    FXString file = FXFile::getHomeDirectory + "/.InDE/settings.cfg";
    if (!FXFile::exists(file))
    {
        // user is running InDE the first time
        FXFile::create(file);
        defaultSettings();
        writeSettings();
    }
    settings->parseFile(file);
    completeSettings();

MainWindow quit method:

    settings->unparseFile(file);

Of course, this is only part of the actual code. I'm still not satisfied 
with it. Everything is a little stagnating
at the moment.

>BTW, have you already implemented something like the new file menu
>command or open or any of these operations?
>  
>
No, I haven't. New file will actually only open a new empty tab in the 
editor, marking it as modified.

>I have actually build up the infrastructure for the new files to test
>the project browser.... but if you've done anything on this, we should
>discuss this beforge merging.
>  
>
Don't hesitate to commit it and I will look at it.

Regards,
Jannis


From devel at sten-net.de  Fri Mar  4 15:10:35 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 15:10:35 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] internationalization & ctags
In-Reply-To: <1109865977.1557.63.camel@jogix.sojox>
References: <1109802540.1541.16.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <422707F0.9050009@sten-net.de> <1109856121.1557.21.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <422715DA.6040506@sten-net.de> <1109865977.1557.63.camel@jogix.sojox>
Message-ID: <42286C5B.4060203@sten-net.de>

Hi Jochen.

>The question is, do we need iterating?
>But reading only those sections at those places, where we need it, would
>save memory, keep the code cleaner, minimize sources for bugs.
>Maybe something like FXbool GUIdirty may be used to indicate, that
>several widgets should reread the settings and mark themself dirty.
>  
>
We won't probably need FXbool GUIdirty since there are only two points 
in the code where settings
are changed:

    1. InDE settings dialog
    2. Project settings dialog

This means, directly after executing those dialogs settings are stored 
and written to the specific
settings file. (We do that in the quit/close project methods once again, 
just to be sure they are written).

At the moment, we have one variable for each option of the settings. We 
won't need the onUpd... and onCmd..
methods if we rewrite the settings dialogs so that they are given the 
values they need before execution (this would
reduce the types of dialogs to one (don't know whether this was 
explained clearly enough).

Instead of calling e.g. settings.editor.font we would use 
settings->find("EDITOR")->find("font"). All we have to make
sure is to add a default value for each variable not being found while 
parsing the settings file (if we call
settings->find("EDITOR")->find("font") without an existing section 
"EDITOR" we would run into a segfault).

As you can see, our first attempt of MainWindow might be totally 
revised. The reason why it's hard to merge
my latest stuff into SVN - I am trying to avoid that you have to arrange 
with a new codebase every few days.
But the codebase yet isn't good enough to develop upon.

My suggestion therefor is that you use the current base for testing and 
working on the project management as
well as creating class with both, header and source file (including a 
license header depending on the project settings)
and so on. That seem to be the things you are highly interested in. 
Luckily, we're writing on an OO program so
merging those parts with a new code base won't cost much of time.

During this, my part would be to heavily think about (and finally, 
write) a new well organized, as compact as
possible structure for InDE. I will also have a look into other, similar 
programs and how they are structured.

What do you think?

Kind regards,
Jannis

> won't need the onUpd... and onCmd..
> methods if we rewrite the settings dialogs so that they are given the 
> values they need before execution (this would
> reduce the types of dialogs to one (don't know whether this was 
> explained clearly enough).
> 
> Instead of calling e.g. settings.editor.font we would use 
> settings->find("EDITOR")->find("font"). All we have to make
> sure is to add a default value for each variable not being found while 
> parsing the settings file (if we call
> settings->find("EDITOR")->find("font") without an existing section 
> "EDITOR" we would run into a segfault).

That's where we started once.
> 
> As you can see, our first attempt of MainWindow might be totally 
> revised. The reason why it's hard to merge
> my latest stuff into SVN - I am trying to avoid that you have to arrange 
> with a new codebase every few days.
> But the codebase yet isn't good enough to develop upon.

I don't mind. I am young and flexible *g*
> 
> My suggestion therefor is that you use the current base for testing and 
> working on the project management as
> well as creating class with both, header and source file (including a 
> license header depending on the project settings)
> and so on. That seem to be the things you are highly interested in. 
> Luckily, we're writing on an OO program so
> merging those parts with a new code base won't cost much of time.

Fortunately the dependencies aren't very important for me, because most
work is done in seperate classes.
But testing the functionality means a) writing testapps, which i do for
certain classes, or b) using InDE for tests, wich is needed for other
things.
Why should i include all code to InDE to test the functionality, if all
this code, which has costed hours of work, is just thrown away and has
to be done completely from ground up again?
> 
> During this, my part would be to heavily think about (and finally, 
> write) a new well organized, as compact as
> possible structure for InDE. I will also have a look into other, similar 
> programs and how they are structured.
> 
Don't loose the sight of it. That's what i think.
Implementing the settings as you proposed in the other mail and
finishing the editor would be a greater job by now. I guess with ongoing
development we will get a need for certain refactorings anyway. So do
it, if you need it, may be more straightforward and more satisfying,
because you see results and not only work to be done and to be thought
about it.

Actually we have no support for different views. What about them? If you
start to think about it, you will most probably be happy, if you arrange
to have a initial release at x-mas. OO supports us in refactoring, for
that we are not developing with something like C, where it is a pain in
the ass to refactor.

Don't get me wrong. Design and a good structure are very important. But
overdesigning can be a shot to the back. There always exists a better
solution, but trying to get the best solution before going on will never
let you go on. Trying to do the best you can at that point may fit best,
making things better at a later time with more knowlege about what is
needed and what blocks will lead to better solutions. At least this is
my point of view.

As far as i am used to develop with Java, i found it normal to rewrite
some classes or to move some code to new classes, which are than
insantiated from this class and so on. This is fun as far as you do it
as soon as it is needed, not earlier. And most of the time you get a
speed boost or some satisfaction because you latly growen code is now
more clear ;)

regards
	Jochen



From devel at sten-net.de  Fri Mar  4 19:20:50 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Fri, 04 Mar 2005 19:20:50 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] internationalization & ctags
In-Reply-To: <1109958691.1542.47.camel@jogix.sojox>
References: <1109802540.1541.16.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <422707F0.9050009@sten-net.de> <1109856121.1557.21.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <422715DA.6040506@sten-net.de> <1109865977.1557.63.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <42286C5B.4060203@sten-net.de> <1109958691.1542.47.camel@jogix.sojox>
Message-ID: <4228A702.90405@sten-net.de>

Jochen Rassler schrieb:

>>Instead of calling e.g. settings.editor.font we would use 
>>settings->find("EDITOR")->find("font"). All we have to make
>>sure is to add a default value for each variable not being found while 
>>parsing the settings file (if we call
>>settings->find("EDITOR")->find("font") without an existing section 
>>"EDITOR" we would run into a segfault).
>>    
>>
>
>That's where we started once.
>  
>
Right. Okay.

I found a better solution. I'm writing a Settings class which can be 
passed a file (which
is created if it doesn't exist already). It also has methods for 
settings default values and for
getting the value by a key (with or without passing the section it can 
be found in).

I think that's the best solution of all. For example if one wants to get 
the editor font, he could
simply use

    settings->getValue("EDITOR", "font");

wherase

    settings->getValue("font")

actually is going to work but might cause collisions with other "font" 
options
in another section.

This class avoids segfaults by using default values for options not 
being defined.
I will try to commit it to SVN tomorrow. After that we will have to 
change the project
settings dialog as well as the InDE settings dialog a little but that 
will only take a few
minutes.

Lots of the onCmd.. and onUpd... methods of MainWindow will be obsolete 
then, so I
will remove them.

Next thing I am changing is the menu bar creation in MainWindow. It will 
be moved
to a function called "buildMenu" or s.th. like that. It already looks 
very well structured
in my local repository.
Another change will be the message map. Currently our way to add a menu 
command handler
would be to add a

    FXMAPFUNC(SEL_COMMAND, MainWindow::ID_OURCOMMAND, 
MainWindow::onCmdOurCommand)

to the message map. The new solution I'd like to describe by an example, 
the file menu.

At first, this menu has a method
    long MainWindow::onFileCmd(FXObject*, ...)

The commands sent by the menu commands in this menu are collected using
    FXMAPFUNCS(SEL_COMMAND, MainWindow::ID_NEW_FILE, MainWidow::ID_QUIT, 
MainWindow::onFileCmd)

onFileCmd would look like this:

long MainWindow::onFileCmd(FXObject*, FXSelector sel, void*)
{
    switch (FXSELID(sel))
    {
       ID_NEW_FILE:
          editor->doSomething();
          break;
       ID_NEW_CLASS:
          showNewClassDialogOrSomething();
          break;
       ID_QUIT:
          quit();
          break;
    };
    return 1;
}

This means, we reduce the handler functions in order to add public functions
which could be called by other widgets directly (not by sending a 
message to MainWindow).

That's an easy to understand well looking structure in my opinion.

However, don't take all those news too serious as they will probably 
change a bit until
tomorrow. But I like it.

Regards,
Jannis

> onFileCmd would look like this:

> long MainWindow::onFileCmd(FXObject*, FXSelector sel, void*)

>     {
>        ID_NEW_FILE:

>           break;

>           break;
>        ID_QUIT:
>           quit();
>           break;

Also sounds good! A bit more structured than the actual approach.
Espacially because the MainWindow class will grow with every new feature
that is application wide.

Let me start a discussion about the "new File" menu command.

Actually i added / changed the file menu to the following structure:

File
+ new >
  + new File
  + new Source
  + new Header
  + new Class
+ quit

That is actually for testing several file creation functions, but i am
not happy with that.

My idea about this is - compared to existing IDE's - a very new
approach:

File
+ new File
...

Project
+ new File(s)
  + Source
  + Header
  + Class
...

That means, if you use File -> new File, you get a new, untitled file,
which you have to store with "save as", and maybe add it to the project
by hand.
Project -> new File -> Source (..) will also produce a new file, but you
name it before it is created and add it to the project. Also it will be
creating the license header, ask for creating other related files, add
the file to SConstruct,....

As far as you have a project opened and a project menu, i always found
it very unstructured to add a file to the project with the file menu.

What do you think about this?
As far as you actually work at the menu structure, this may be the time
to do it this way.

regards
	Jochen

PS: does FOX have something like FXObjectList for objects, not for
pointers to objects? I haven't found anything yet and therefore used a
std::vector<FXString>. It is ok, works fine, uses a clear and well known
API, but doing it the FOX way if FOX supports this, would be nicer ;)

Hi Jochen.

Yes, it is. You can use append() (and probably prepend() or insert()) 
for adding items to
the array. no() returns the size of the array.

- Jannis


From devel at sten-net.de  Mon Mar  7 21:21:44 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Mon, 07 Mar 2005 21:21:44 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Delay
Message-ID: <422CB7D8.1090705@sten-net.de>

Hi Jochen.

I apologize the delay of my commit but there are some things I'm still 
working on.

The settings API is already done. We won't need to load the settings 
file from
~/.foxrc/FoxDefault/InDE but instead have a file which is called 
~/.InDE/settings.cfg
The functionality provided by the API can also be used for the project 
settings.

The tabbed editor already has minimalistic functionality like opening, 
closing
and saving one or all opened files and adjusting the font. That's ok for 
now and
I will further work on that after my commit.

Currently, I rewrite my SettingsDialog after moving the functionality to 
load
and store the values it modifies into the class itself (instead of 
MainWindow).
There are some generic thoughts about what should be in MainWindow and what
in the dialogs/widgets but I will report on that later.

Next thing: I had a look into some documentation tools. I tested doxygen 
for example,
but it didn't satisfy me. So I went for NaturalDocs 
(www.naturaldocs.org) which
offers very clean documentation syntax and neat looking layout. We can 
discuss this
on the list but my next commit will already include NaturalDocs 
documentated headers
for all classes.

And another topic I'd shortly report about: I know you're working on the 
project browser
so I tweaked the filesystem browser a little bit. There are context 
menus for directories
and files now, both for opening one or more files and importing files 
and directories.
They already use the minimalistic TabEditor API which you will get to 
know tomorrow, I
hope.

Best Regards,
Jannis

The project browser is nearly finished. Things that are left to do are
the savings of the file lists and in InDE itself (not in the project
browser) the additions of files to the browser. 
As far as i see it is more sensefull to wait for your code to be checked
in to finish the browser. So i do not need to rewrite this code.

But it will only be a question of few hours to implement and test.

And some artworks are missing.... ;) 

BTW, while implementing the project browser i thought about possible
project structures.
One may wish to have a src/ dir and then split some modules to several
subdirs. E.g. 
src/main.cpp
src/some_other_stuff.cpp
src/module1/module1_implementation.cpp
src/module2/module2_implementation.cpp
...

I haven't included support for this yet. But i will have a look at this
later (for InDE > 0.1).

My primaryly plans are to get the basic project browser to work, include
it to InDE functionality. After that the inclusion of the GPL and LGPL
headers for new files will be added.
As soon as the project settings work with the new structure for
mainwindow,... i will start implementing the SConstruct file creation,
which will be the hardest job of this list.

As soon as this work is done, i am fine to have an initial release.
Hopefully we can get our timelines together so far.
Maybe we can run for the weekend of March 18th-20th?

regards,
	Jochen

Jannis


From jochen at cornmania.de  Tue Mar  8 12:20:41 2005
From: jochen at cornmania.de (Jochen Rassler)
Date: Tue, 08 Mar 2005 12:20:41 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Delay
In-Reply-To: <422D81F2.6050608@sten-net.de>
References: <422CB7D8.1090705@sten-net.de>
	 <1110274779.1541.20.camel@jogix.sojox>  <422D81F2.6050608@sten-net.de>
Message-ID: <1110280841.1541.37.camel@jogix.sojox>

Ha Jannis.

Am Dienstag, den 08.03.2005, 11:44 +0100 schrieb Jannis Pohlmann:
> Hi Jochen.
> 
> >As far as i have another exam in a few hours i had no time to work on
> >InDE this weekend. 
> >  
> >
> Oh, good luck then.

Thanks.

> 
> >>The settings API is already done. We won't need to load the settings 
> >>file from
> >>~/.foxrc/FoxDefault/InDE but instead have a file which is called 
> >>~/.InDE/settings.cfg
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >why *.cfg? Is this meant for Windows compatibility?
> >  
> >
> Hm, no. We give it any extension. What do you prefer? .ini would be 
> logical but unusual for Linux whereas
> .conf would be the Linux way.

I prefer *.conf or no extension. As far as this is a settings for Unix,
we do not need a extension. If the file is named .InDE/settings it is
clear what it does. But if extension, i prefer *.conf, because it's the
Unix way.
> 
> >But it will only be a question of few hours to implement and test.
> >
> >And some artworks are missing.... ;) 
> >  
> >
> Yes. I had a look at tons of icon archives (both, KDE-/Gnome-like and 
> Windows). I came to the conclusion
> that best would be to use typical Windows 2000 or XP icons. Wait a few 
> days and I will upload an archive
> which you can look at.

Are these icons free?
If not, we can not use them because of the GPL of InDE.
> 
> >BTW, while implementing the project browser i thought about possible
> >project structures.
> >One may wish to have a src/ dir and then split some modules to several
> >subdirs. E.g. 
> >src/main.cpp
> >src/some_other_stuff.cpp
> >src/module1/module1_implementation.cpp
> >src/module2/module2_implementation.cpp
> >...
> >
> >I haven't included support for this yet. But i will have a look at this
> >later (for InDE > 0.1).
> >  
> >
> Okay.
> 
> >As soon as the project settings work with the new structure for
> >mainwindow,... i will start implementing the SConstruct file creation,
> >which will be the hardest job of this list.
> >  
> >
> Yes, that's going to be hard - especially if we consider that later the 
> user might have to add different
> libraries for each platform he wants his software to be built on. For 
> that, our settings class
> might need something like a
>      typedef FXArray<FXString> StringArray
> and functions like
>     setStringArrayValue()
>     getStringArrayValue()
> 
> But we will see.

I guess we have to carry some information together to locate the
problems. 
I have some ideas, but haven't thought in depth to all upcomming
problems. This will most probably be a topic next week(end).

But on the other hand, we could arrange this to be solved in later
versions more intelligent. As far as we use the project settings, one
can specify all needed libraries there and depending on this the correct
SConstruct is build. As soon as you move the project to another
plattform, it is needed to revise the project settings to change the
libraries.
I guess, that will do it for the very first release. (I also guess that
noone will use InDE 0.1 for large projects and especially not for too
complicated cross plattform projects)

All in depth SConstruct buildings depend on the task i added about the
project settings to know the compiler and OS. 

For all this we need to know compiler switches, library names (or
differences in them), linker options and so on. This will also be very
interesting for debugging support.....
> 
> >As soon as this work is done, i am fine to have an initial release.
> >Hopefully we can get our timelines together so far.
> >Maybe we can run for the weekend of March 18th-20th?
> >  
> >
> That should be possible, I think.

Just to mention:
for the release we should add GPL headers to all files, an AUTHOR,
LICENSE, README and INSTALL file. The GPL headers can use a link to the
AUTHOR's file, to avoid future problems, if a new developer joins the
project *g*

So far. I guess this one was the last for this morning. I have to leave
soon for the exam...

regards,
	Jochen



From devel at sten-net.de  Tue Mar  8 20:28:29 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Tue, 08 Mar 2005 20:28:29 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Instructions: Using NaturalDocs for generating API docs
Message-ID: <422DFCDD.8020607@sten-net.de>

Hi Jochen.

As already mentioned, I'd like to use NaturalDocs (naturaldocs.org) in 
order to generate the API documentation
for InDE.

I've commited my latest work to SVN and added a file called
   
    gendoc.sh

You can download NaturalDocs, and (for example) move it to
   
    /opt/NaturalDocs/

If you then create a symlink like this:

    ln -s /opt/NaturalDocs/NaturalDocs /usr/local/bin/NaturalDocs

You can simply run ./gendoc.sh in order to generate the documentation. 
Since this is absolutely optional, I
don't think we should integrate it into the SConstruct file for InDE.

Regards,
Jannis


From devel at sten-net.de  Tue Mar  8 20:51:51 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Tue, 08 Mar 2005 20:51:51 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] API changes/news
Message-ID: <422E0257.6020106@sten-net.de>

Hi Jochen.

I finally got my stuff commited to SVN. I removed your dialogs since the 
current SVN trunk
wouldn't build anymore with them (and I didn't want to do your work by 
changing them). You
may of course integrate them again.

Some notes (besides the API docs you can look at in doc/index.html) on 
the most
important API changes:

Class: InDE (previously called "App")
    - removed syntax file loading functionality (is now handled by 
TabEditor)

Class: MainWindow
    - all onCmd... and onUpd... functions
    + a public member variable "settings" which is an object of the 
class Settings
    > onCmdEditSettings() to editSettings()
    + methods applySettings(), resetSettings()
    + method readSettings() - default values are defined here
    + methods to build menus and content: buildMenu(), buildContent()
    + variable "editor" (class TabEditor) and method getEditor()
    > settings file is now created in ~/.InDE/. It's called "settings" 
without
      any extension on linux. On Windows, it is created as 
~/InDE/settings.ini
    ...

Class: SettingsDialog
    + method run() to execute the dialog
    + methods loadValues() and storeValues() (that's no longer handled 
by MainWindow)
    + some options

Class: Settings
    + All methods are written in two ways: with and without section 
parameter. The ones
      without a section parameter use section "GENERAL"
    + methods: setDefault() for integer and string values.
    + methods: getStringValue(), getIntValue() and getFormatValue() (the 
latter probably
      won't work already)
    + methods setStringValue, setIntValue() and setFormatValue() (the 
latter probably
      won't work)
    + methods parse(), read() and write()
    + method defaults(FXbool) for either filling missing values or 
filling and replacing
      all values with defaults defined using setDefault

Class: TabItem
    + Enhancement of FXTabItem. Can send messages to a target.

Class: Edit
    + represents an opened document/file
    + methods getFilename(), setFilename(), isModified() and setModified()
    + method setTitleTab() for connecting to a TabItem object which 
displays the
      file's basename
    + method setSyntax() for settings the syntax for the document

Class: TabEditor
    + tons of methods for loading a syntax file, determining the syntax 
of documents,
      opening, closing and saving one, more or all documents, and so on ...

Class: FileBrowser
    + Enhanced FXDirList. Provides context menus for files and 
directories like opening,
      importing and deleting.

I hope this helps. If you have any questions - ask them!

Kind regards,
Jannis


From devel at sten-net.de  Tue Mar  8 21:07:26 2005

From devel at sten-net.de  Tue Mar  8 21:39:35 2005

One thing I forgot to mention: Syntax highlighting already works fine, 
but the colors cannot be configured yet.
Therefor I added my current ~/.InDE/settings file to the share/ 
directory in SVN. You can simply copy
the section "STYLE" into your settings file, then start InDE.

Regards,
Jannis

-- this job would be done by berlios.

Mailinglist: the script generates a mail to notify the users that new
versions have been commited to svn,....

>What about a cvn tree for the api docs. As far as i remember, there is a
>possibility on berlios to generate webcontents from svn trees. So we
>just have to commit the api-doc, but do not have to update the website
>-- this job would be done by berlios.
>  
>
Might be possible, yes. The API docs already are accessable from SVN on

    http://svn.berlios.de/viewcvs/*checkout*/inde/trunk/doc/index.html

If there is a script provided by BerliOS it would be great to copy them 
from SVN to
   
    /home/groups/inde/htdocs/doc/

whenever the SVN tree is updated.

I'm not sure whether a stand-alone tree for the docs is necessary since 
theay are directly
connected to the sourcecode - it's only logical to update them with 
every change in the code.

Regards,
Jannis

From devel at sten-net.de  Thu Mar 10 17:27:43 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 17:27:43 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] r25 - in trunk: doc/NaturalDocs/Data include src
In-Reply-To: <1110456230.1541.20.camel@jogix.sojox>
References: <200503101027.j2AARAIj006941@sheep.berlios.de>	 <4230237B.50605@sten-net.de> <1110452135.1541.13.camel@jogix.sojox>	 <4230316E.8080101@sten-net.de> <1110456230.1541.20.camel@jogix.sojox>
Message-ID: <4230757F.2080704@sten-net.de>

Hi Jochen.

>>By the way, I made the api/ directory on our website a local SVN working 
>>copy of /trunk/doc. So
>>whenever you commit changes in the API docs it would be great if you 
>>could run "svn update"
>>in that directory. I am still searching for the ability to add a cronjob 
>>for that on the shell.berlios.de
>>server.
>>    
>>
>
>why a svn update in this directory? If i am in trunk and do a svn
>update, doesn't that just do the right thing?
>
>Jochen
>
You probably misunderstood.

Normally, when you're commiting your work the commit will include the 
API docs in doc/ as well.
But of course this won't update the API docs linked on the website. So I 
made the website
directory api/ a local working copy of trunk/doc/. This means one can 
easily sync the ones
on the website with those on SVN by typing "svn update" (after logging 
in on shell.berlios.de
and switching to the directory /home/groups/inde/htdocs/api/).

This has nothing to do with what you do with the local working copy on 
your home computer.

But I think it's still too complicated. I am going to check if redirecting

    http://inde.berlios.de/api/*
to
    http://svn.berlios.de/viewcvs/*checkout*/inde/trunk/doc/*

works with the help of mod_rewrite and whether this would make browsing 
the docs less
fast.

Regards,
Jannis

+ of this license document, but changing it is not allowed.

+			    Preamble
+
+  The licenses for most software are designed to take away your
+freedom to share and change it.  By contrast, the GNU General Public
+License is intended to guarantee your freedom to share and change free
+software--to make sure the software is free for all its users.  This
+General Public License applies to most of the Free Software
+Foundation's software and to any other program whose authors commit to
+using it.  (Some other Free Software Foundation software is covered by
+the GNU Library General Public License instead.)  You can apply it to
+your programs, too.
+
+  When we speak of free software, we are referring to freedom, not
+price.  Our General Public Licenses are designed to make sure that you
+have the freedom to distribute copies of free software (and charge for
+this service if you wish), that you receive source code or can get it
+if you want it, that you can change the software or use pieces of it
+in new free programs; and that you know you can do these things.
+
+  To protect your rights, we need to make restrictions that forbid
+anyone to deny you these rights or to ask you to surrender the rights.
+These restrictions translate to certain responsibilities for you if you
+distribute copies of the software, or if you modify it.
+
+  For example, if you distribute copies of such a program, whether
+gratis or for a fee, you must give the recipients all the rights that
+you have.  You must make sure that they, too, receive or can get the
+source code.  And you must show them these terms so they know their
+rights.
+
+  We protect your rights with two steps: (1) copyright the software, and
+(2) offer you this license which gives you legal permission to copy,
+distribute and/or modify the software.
+
+  Also, for each author's protection and ours, we want to make certain
+that everyone understands that there is no warranty for this free
+software.  If the software is modified by someone else and passed on, we
+want its recipients to know that what they have is not the original, so
+that any problems introduced by others will not reflect on the original
+authors' reputations.
+
+  Finally, any free program is threatened constantly by software
+patents.  We wish to avoid the danger that redistributors of a free
+program will individually obtain patent licenses, in effect making the
+program proprietary.  To prevent this, we have made it clear that any
+patent must be licensed for everyone's free use or not licensed at all.
+
+  The precise terms and conditions for copying, distribution and
+modification follow.

+		    GNU GENERAL PUBLIC LICENSE
+   TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR COPYING, DISTRIBUTION AND MODIFICATION
+
+  0. This License applies to any program or other work which contains
+a notice placed by the copyright holder saying it may be distributed
+under the terms of this General Public License.  The "Program", below,
+refers to any such program or work, and a "work based on the Program"
+means either the Program or any derivative work under copyright law:
+that is to say, a work containing the Program or a portion of it,
+either verbatim or with modifications and/or translated into another
+language.  (Hereinafter, translation is included without limitation in
+the term "modification".)  Each licensee is addressed as "you".
+
+Activities other than copying, distribution and modification are not
+covered by this License; they are outside its scope.  The act of
+running the Program is not restricted, and the output from the Program
+is covered only if its contents constitute a work based on the
+Program (independent of having been made by running the Program).
+Whether that is true depends on what the Program does.
+
+  1. You may copy and distribute verbatim copies of the Program's
+source code as you receive it, in any medium, provided that you
+conspicuously and appropriately publish on each copy an appropriate
+copyright notice and disclaimer of warranty; keep intact all the
+notices that refer to this License and to the absence of any warranty;
+and give any other recipients of the Program a copy of this License
+along with the Program.
+
+You may charge a fee for the physical act of transferring a copy, and
+you may at your option offer warranty protection in exchange for a fee.
+
+  2. You may modify your copy or copies of the Program or any portion
+of it, thus forming a work based on the Program, and copy and
+distribute such modifications or work under the terms of Section 1
+above, provided that you also meet all of these conditions:
+
+    a) You must cause the modified files to carry prominent notices
+    stating that you changed the files and the date of any change.
+
+    b) You must cause any work that you distribute or publish, that in
+    whole or in part contains or is derived from the Program or any
+    part thereof, to be licensed as a whole at no charge to all third
+    parties under the terms of this License.
+
+    c) If the modified program normally reads commands interactively
+    when run, you must cause it, when started running for such
+    interactive use in the most ordinary way, to print or display an
+    announcement including an appropriate copyright notice and a
+    notice that there is no warranty (or else, saying that you provide
+    a warranty) and that users may redistribute the program under
+    these conditions, and telling the user how to view a copy of this
+    License.  (Exception: if the Program itself is interactive but
+    does not normally print such an announcement, your work based on
+    the Program is not required to print an announcement.)
+
+These requirements apply to the modified work as a whole.  If
+identifiable sections of that work are not derived from the Program,
+and can be reasonably considered independent and separate works in
+themselves, then this License, and its terms, do not apply to those
+sections when you distribute them as separate works.  But when you
+distribute the same sections as part of a whole which is a work based
+on the Program, the distribution of the whole must be on the terms of
+this License, whose permissions for other licensees extend to the
+entire whole, and thus to each and every part regardless of who wrote it.
+
+Thus, it is not the intent of this section to claim rights or contest
+your rights to work written entirely by you; rather, the intent is to
+exercise the right to control the distribution of derivative or
+collective works based on the Program.
+
+In addition, mere aggregation of another work not based on the Program
+with the Program (or with a work based on the Program) on a volume of
+a storage or distribution medium does not bring the other work under
+the scope of this License.

+  3. You may copy and distribute the Program (or a work based on it,
+under Section 2) in object code or executable form under the terms of
+Sections 1 and 2 above provided that you also do one of the following:
+
+    a) Accompany it with the complete corresponding machine-readable
+    source code, which must be distributed under the terms of Sections
+    1 and 2 above on a medium customarily used for software interchange; or,
+
+    b) Accompany it with a written offer, valid for at least three
+    years, to give any third party, for a charge no more than your
+    cost of physically performing source distribution, a complete
+    machine-readable copy of the corresponding source code, to be
+    distributed under the terms of Sections 1 and 2 above on a medium
+    customarily used for software interchange; or,

+    c) Accompany it with the information you received as to the offer
+    to distribute corresponding source code.  (This alternative is
+    allowed only for noncommercial distribution and only if you
+    received the program in object code or executable form with such
+    an offer, in accord with Subsection b above.)
+
+The source code for a work means the preferred form of the work for
+making modifications to it.  For an executable work, complete source
+code means all the source code for all modules it contains, plus any
+associated interface definition files, plus the scripts used to
+control compilation and installation of the executable.  However, as a
+special exception, the source code distributed need not include
+anything that is normally distributed (in either source or binary
+form) with the major components (compiler, kernel, and so on) of the
+operating system on which the executable runs, unless that component
+itself accompanies the executable.
+
+If distribution of executable or object code is made by offering
+access to copy from a designated place, then offering equivalent
+access to copy the source code from the same place counts as
+distribution of the source code, even though third parties are not
+compelled to copy the source along with the object code.
+
+  4. You may not copy, modify, sublicense, or distribute the Program
+except as expressly provided under this License.  Any attempt
+otherwise to copy, modify, sublicense or distribute the Program is
+void, and will automatically terminate your rights under this License.
+However, parties who have received copies, or rights, from you under
+this License will not have their licenses terminated so long as such
+parties remain in full compliance.

+  5. You are not required to accept this License, since you have not
+signed it.  However, nothing else grants you permission to modify or
+distribute the Program or its derivative works.  These actions are
+prohibited by law if you do not accept this License.  Therefore, by
+modifying or distributing the Program (or any work based on the
+Program), you indicate your acceptance of this License to do so, and
+all its terms and conditions for copying, distributing or modifying
+the Program or works based on it.

+Program), the recipient automatically receives a license from the
+original licensor to copy, distribute or modify the Program subject to
+these terms and conditions.  You may not impose any further
+restrictions on the recipients' exercise of the rights granted herein.
+You are not responsible for enforcing compliance by third parties to
+this License.

+infringement or for any other reason (not limited to patent issues),

+refrain entirely from distribution of the Program.

Added: trunk/doc/README
===================================================================
--- trunk/doc/README	2005-03-10 10:27:09 UTC (rev 25)
+++ trunk/doc/README	2005-03-10 17:37:18 UTC (rev 26)
@@ -0,0 +1,154 @@
+===============================================================================
+                                 InDE README
+===============================================================================
+
+                               I. Introduction
+                              II. Requirements
+                             III. Getting InDE
+                              IV. Installation
+                               V. Getting started
+                              VI. Help and Support
+                             VII. Bug reports
+                            VIII. Joining development
+                              IX. License
+
+===============================================================================
+
+
+
+I. Introduction
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+You may ask yourself: What is InDE? 
+We often call it "a fast and pragmatic C/C++ IDE". This means InDE is a program
+which you can use to write software. There are tons of useful features which 
+make developing fun:
+
+	<list of features>
+	
+<note on platform independent software development with SCons>
+
+
+
+II. Requirements
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+You at least need:
+
+	- Python >= 2.3
+	- SCons >= 0.93
+	- FOX >= 1.5.0
+
+
+
+III. Getting InDE
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+There are many ways to get InDE packages for your machine. The most common way
+is to visit our website at http://inde.berlios.de/ and download the latest
+stable (or development) release.
+
+If you use Linux, your distribution might already offer pre-compiled InDE 
+packages.
+
+Another way is to get our daily development snapshot at:
+	
+	http://inde.berlios.de/download/inde-snapshot.tar.bz2
+
+Finally, you can checkout the current Subversion tree by using the SVN command
+line client:
+
+	svn checkout svn://svn.berlios.de/projects/inde/trunk
+
+
+
+IV. Installation
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+After downloading the latest release or our daily development snapshot 
+from our website you will have to unpack and change to the directory
+you unpacked the archive at first:
+
+	tar xvjf <archive name>.tar.bz2
+	cd <archive name>/
+
+If you checked out the source from our SVN tree, go to the directory inde/trunk
+if you are not already in it.
+
+After this, every method will build and install using the same instructions, 
+that are:
+	
+	scons				-	Compiling
+	scons -c			-	Cleaning up the build
+	scons install		-	Install InDE
+	scons -c install	-	Uninstall InDE
+	scons docs			-	Make docs (they can be found in doc/)
+	
+You can get more information about available commands and parameters using
+
+	scons --help
+	
+	
+
+V. Getting started
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+While you are reading this README we probably might have created some 
+documentation for InDE already. You can read them by opening
+
+	docs/index.html
+	
+with a web browser of your choice. They are mostly validated XHTML documents so
+you can view them even with a text browser like Lynx.
+
+
+
+VI. Help and Support
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+If you run into problems or like to see new features getting integrated into
+InDE, feel free to join the InDE-users mailinglist at:
+
+	<mailing-list url>
+
+If you think you have found a bug, see next section for instructions on how to 
+let us now about them.
+
+Please let us know if you are using InDE for developing a certain software. 
+This way we can support you by an entry in the "Projects" list on our website.
+
+
+VII. Bug reports
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+You can report bugs either by posting them at
+
+	<bug-tracker url>
+
+or joining the InDE-devel mailinglist at
+
+	<mailing-list url>
+
+
+
+VIII. Joining development
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+There are many ways to contribute to InDE:
+	
+	- Translating InDE into another language
+	- Taking part in discussions on the InDE-devel mailinglist 
+	- Taking over maintenance for InDE packages for your Linux/BSD distribution
+	
+	<list of other possibilities>
+
+
+
+IX. License
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+InDE is licensed under GNU GPL. Its complete contents can be found in the
+LICENSE file.
+
+
+Thanks for using InDE!

+void Settings::setColorValue(const FXString& key, FXColor value)
+{
+	setColorValue("GENERAL", key, value);
+}
+
+void Settings::setColorValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key, FXColor value)
+{
+	FXTRACE((1, "Settings::setColorValue(%s, %s, %i)\n", section.text(), key.text(), value));
+	writeColorEntry(section.text(), key.text(), value);
+}
+
+void Settings::setDefaultColor(const FXString& key, FXColor value)
+{
+	setDefaultColor("GENERAL", key, value);
+}
+
+void Settings::setDefaultColor(const FXString& section, const FXString& key, FXColor value)
+{
+	FXTRACE((1, "Settings::setDefault(%s, %s, %i)\n", section.text(), key.text(), -value));
+	defaultDict->writeColorEntry(section.text(), key.text(), value);
+}
+
+FXColor Settings::getColorValue(const FXString& key)
+{
+	return getColorValue("GENERAL", key);
+}
+
+FXColor Settings::getColorValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key)
+{
+	return readColorEntry(section.text(), key.text());
+}

 void TabEditor::appendDocument()
@@ -497,3 +498,31 @@
 	}
 	setCurrent(getCurrent()-1);
 }
+
+void TabEditor::applySettings()
+{
+	FXTRACE((1, "TabEditor::applySettings()\n"));
+	Settings* reg = mainWin->settings;
+	setFont(reg->getStringValue("EDITOR", "font"));
+	setSyntaxFile(reg->getStringValue("EDITOR", "syntaxFile"));
+	showLineNumbers(reg->getIntValue("EDITOR", "lineNumbers"));
+	for (FXuint i = 0; i < numChildren()/2; i++)
+	{
+		applySettingsTo(i);
+	}
+}
+
+void TabEditor::applySettingsTo(FXuint index)
+{
+	FXTRACE((1, "TabEditor::applySettingsTo(%i)\n", index));
+	if (!numChildren() || index >= numChildren()/2)
+	{
+		return;
+	}
+	Settings* reg = mainWin->settings;
+	Edit* doc = documentAt(index);
+	doc->setNumberColor(reg->getColorValue("COLORS", "numberColor"));
+	doc->setBarColor(reg->getColorValue("COLORS", "barColor"));
+	doc->setTextColor(reg->getColorValue("COLORS", "foreColor"));
+	doc->setBackColor(reg->getColorValue("COLORS", "backColor"));
+}

Modified: trunk/src/Edit.cpp
===================================================================
--- trunk/src/Edit.cpp	2005-03-10 18:01:17 UTC (rev 27)
+++ trunk/src/Edit.cpp	2005-03-10 20:31:09 UTC (rev 28)
@@ -77,3 +77,86 @@
 {
 	syntax = syn;
 }
+
+FXint Edit::findRestylePoint(FXint pos, FXint& style) const
+{
+	register FXint probepos, safepos, beforesafepos, runstyle, s;
+	style = 0;
+	probepos = backwardByContext(pos);
+	if (probepos == 0)
+		return 0;
+	runstyle = getStyle(probepos);
+	if (runstyle == 0)
+		return probepos;
+
+	safepos = backwardByContext(probepos);
+	beforesafepos = backwardByContext(safepos);
+
+	for (--probepos; 0 < probepos; --probepos)
+	{
+		s = getStyle(probepos);
+		if (s == runstyle)
+		{
+			if (probepos <= beforesafepos)
+			{
+				style = runstyle;
+				return safepos;
+			}
+			continue;
+		}
+
+		if (syntax->isAncestor(s, runstyle))
+		{
+			style = s;
+			return probepos + 1;
+		}
+
+		if (syntax->isAncestor(runstyle, s))
+		{
+			style = runstyle;
+			return probepos + 1;
+		}
+
+	    if (syntax->getRule(s)->getParent() == syntax->getRule(runstyle)->getParent())
+	    {
+			style = syntax->getRule(s)->getParent();
+			return probepos + 1;
+		}
+
+		return probepos+1;
+	}
+	return 0;
+}
+
+FXint Edit::backwardByContext(FXint pos) const
+{
+	register FXint nlines = syntax->getContextLines();
+	register FXint nchars = syntax->getContextChars();
+	register FXint result = pos;
+	if (1 < nlines)
+	{
+		result = prevLine(pos,nlines-1);
+	}
+	else if (nlines == 1)
+	{
+		result = lineStart(pos);
+	}
+	if (pos - nchars < result)
+		result = pos - nchars;
+	if (result < 0)
+		result = 0;
+	return result;
+}
+
+FXint Edit::forwardByContext(FXint pos) const
+{
+	register FXint nlines = syntax->getContextLines();
+	register FXint nchars = syntax->getContextChars();
+	register FXint result = pos;
+	result = nextLine(pos, nlines);
+	if (pos + nchars > result)
+		result = pos + nchars;
+	if (result > getLength())
+		result = getLength();
+	return result;
+}

 #include <fstream>
 #include <fxkeys.h>
 
+#define RESTYLEJUMP     80
+
 FXDEFMAP(TabEditor) TabEditorMap[] = {
 	FXMAPFUNC(SEL_RIGHTBUTTONRELEASE,	TabEditor::ID_TAB_MENU,		TabEditor::onTabMenu),
 	FXMAPFUNCS(SEL_COMMAND,				TabEditor::ID_NEW,
@@ -385,6 +387,75 @@

 }
 
+FXint TabEditor::restyleRange(FXuint index, FXint beg, FXint end, FXint& head, FXint& tail, FXint rule)
+{
+	FXTRACE((1, "TabEditor::restyleRange(%i, %i, %i, %i, %i, %i)\n", index, beg, end, head, tail, rule));
+	Edit* edit = documentAt(index);
+	FXchar* text;
+	FXchar* newstyle;
+	FXchar* oldstyle;
+	register FXint len = end - beg;
+	register FXint delta = len;
+	FXASSERT(0 <= rule);
+	FXASSERT(0 <= beg && beg <= end && end <= edit->getLength());
+	FXMALLOC(&text, FXchar, len + len + len);
+	newstyle = text + len;
+	oldstyle = text + len + len;
+	edit->extractText(text, beg, len);
+	edit->extractStyle(oldstyle, beg, len);
+	edit->getSyntax()->getRule(rule)->stylizeBody(text, newstyle, 0, len, head, tail);
+	edit->changeStyle(beg, len, newstyle);
+	while(0 < delta && oldstyle[delta-1] == newstyle[delta-1])
+		--delta;
+	FXFREE(&text);
+	head += beg;
+	tail += beg;
+	delta += beg;
+	FXTRACE((1,"changed head=%d tail=%d same till delta=%d\n",head,tail,delta));
+	return delta;
+}
+
+void TabEditor::restyleDocument(FXuint index, FXint pos, FXint del, FXint ins)
+{
+	FXTRACE((1, "TabEditor::restyleDocument(%i, %i, %i, %i)\n", index, pos, del, ins));
+	Edit* edit = documentAt(index);
+	FXint head, tail, changed, affected, beg, end, len, rule, restylejump;
+	if(edit->getSyntax())
+	{
+		len = edit->getLength();
+		changed = pos + ins;
+		beg = edit->findRestylePoint(pos,rule);
+		end = edit->forwardByContext(changed);
+		FXASSERT(0 <= rule);
+		restylejump = RESTYLEJUMP;
+		while (1)
+		{
+			affected = restyleRange(index, beg, end, head, tail, rule);
+			if (tail < end)
+			{
+				beg = tail;
+				if (rule == 0)
+				{
+					fxwarning("Top level patterns did not color everything.\n");
+					return;
+				}
+				rule = edit->getSyntax()->getRule(rule)->getParent();
+				continue;
+			}
+			if (affected > changed)
+			{
+				restylejump <<= 1;
+				changed = affected;
+				end = changed + restylejump;
+				if (end > len)
+					end = len;
+				continue;
+			}
+			return;
+		}
+	}
+}
+
 void TabEditor::restyleDocument(FXuint index)
 {
 	FXTRACE((1, "TabEditor::restyleDocument(%i)\n", index));
@@ -406,30 +477,24 @@
 	}
 }

 	FXTRACE((1, "TabEditor::onTextInserted()\n"));
 	FXuint index = indexOfChild(((Edit*)sender)->getParent()->getParent());
-	Edit* edit = (Edit*)sender;
-	edit->setModified();
-	if (edit->getSyntax())
-	{
-		restyleDocument(index);
-	}
+	((Edit*)sender)->setModified();
+	const FXTextChange* change = (const FXTextChange*)ptr;
+	restyleDocument(index, change->pos,change->ndel,change->nins);
 	return 1;
 }

-	Edit* edit = (Edit*)sender;
-	edit->setModified();
-	if (edit->getSyntax())
-	{
-		restyleDocument(index);
-	}

+	const FXTextChange* change = (const FXTextChange*)ptr;

 	return 1;
 }
 
@@ -442,16 +507,13 @@
 }

Added: trunk/include/NewProjectWizard.h

--- trunk/include/NewProjectWizard.h	2005-03-10 20:31:09 UTC (rev 28)
+++ trunk/include/NewProjectWizard.h	2005-03-11 13:00:42 UTC (rev 29)
@@ -0,0 +1,137 @@
+#ifndef NEWPROJECTWIZARD_H
+#define NEWPROJECTWIZARD_H
+
+#include <fx.h>
+#include "InDE.h"
+#include "MainWindow.h"
+#include "DialogTitle.h"
+
+class MainWindow;
+
+/*
+	Class: NewProjectWizard
+
+	NewProjectWizards provides several depending dialogs for the
+	creation of a new InDE project
+*/
+class NewProjectWizard : public FXWizard  {
+
+	FXDECLARE(NewProjectWizard)
+
+	public:
+		FXString		type;
+		
+		FXString		name;
+		FXString		description;
+		FXString		target;
+		FXString		version;
+		FXString		author;
+		FXString		mail;
+		FXint			license;
+		FXString		licenseHeader;
+		
+		FXString		includePaths;
+		FXString		libraryPaths;
+		FXString		libraries;
+		
+		FXString		srcDir;
+		FXString		includeDir;
+		FXString		buildDir;
+		
+		FXString		warnings;
+		FXString		defines;
+		FXString		switches;
+		FXbool			debug;
+		FXbool			pic;
+
+	private:
+		FXDataTarget	tgtType;
+		
+		FXDataTarget	tgtName;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtDescription;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtTarget;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtVersion;
+		
+		FXDataTarget	tgtIncludePaths;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtLibraryPaths;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtLibraries;
+		
+		FXDataTarget	tgtSrcDir;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtIncludeDir;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtBuildDir;
+		
+		FXDataTarget	tgtWarnings;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtDefines;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtSwitches;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtDebug;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtPic;
+
+		FXDataTarget	tgtAuthor;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtMail;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtLicense;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtLicenseHeader;
+	
+	private:
+
+		FXVerticalFrame* step1;
+		FXVerticalFrame* step2;
+		FXVerticalFrame* step3;
+		FXVerticalFrame* step4;
+		FXVerticalFrame* step5;
+
+	protected:
+		NewProjectWizard() {};
+		NewProjectWizard(const NewProjectWizard&);
+		NewProjectWizard& operator=(const NewProjectWizard&);
+
+	public:
+		enum {
+			ID_SELECTLICENSEFILE = FXWizard::ID_LAST,
+			ID_LAST
+		};
+
+	public:
+		long onCmdSelectLicenseHeader(FXObject*, FXSelector, void*);
+				
+	public:
+	
+		/*
+			Constructor: NewProjectWizard
+		*/
+		NewProjectWizard(MainWindow* owner, const FXString& name);
+		
+		/*
+			Function: Create
+		*/
+		virtual void create();
+		
+		/*
+			Destructor: ~NewProjectWizard
+		*/
+		virtual ~NewProjectWizard();
+		
+		/*
+			Function: check
+
+			checks if the user provided us with the needed information
+		*/
+		FXbool check();
+
+		/*
+			Function: run
+
+			starts execution of NewProjectWizard
+		*/
+		void run();
+
+		/*
+			Function: storeValues
+
+			saves the project settings
+		*/
+		void storeValues();
+
+};
+
+
+#endif // NEWPROJECTWIZARD_H

Added: trunk/include/ProjectBrowser.h
===================================================================
--- trunk/include/ProjectBrowser.h	2005-03-10 20:31:09 UTC (rev 28)
+++ trunk/include/ProjectBrowser.h	2005-03-11 13:00:42 UTC (rev 29)
@@ -0,0 +1,176 @@
+#ifndef PROJECTBROWSER_H
+#define PROJECTBROWSER_H
+
+#include <fx.h>
+#include "InDE.h"
+#include "ProjectSettings.h"
+
+
+/*
+	Class: ProjectBrowser
+
+	ProjectBrowser is a special FXTreeList like Widget, which provides 
+	some functionality to easyly add new projects and files to its view.
+*/
+class ProjectBrowser : public FXComposite 
+{
+	FXDECLARE(ProjectBrowser)
+
+	private:
+		FXTreeList		*projectTree;
+
+	protected:
+		ProjectBrowser() {}
+		ProjectBrowser(const ProjectBrowser&) {}
+
+	public:
+		enum FileType {
+			CPP_SOURCE,
+			CPP_HEADER,
+			RESSOURCE_FILE,
+			SCONS,
+			TEXT
+		};
+		enum DirType {
+			SOURCE,
+			INCLUDE,
+			RESSOURCE
+		};
+
+	public:
+		/*
+			Constructor: ProjectBrowser
+		*/
+		ProjectBrowser(FXComposite *p, FXObject *tgt = NULL, FXSelector sel = 0, FXuint opts = 0, FXint x = 0, FXint y = 0, FXint w = 0, FXint h = 0);
+
+		/*
+			Destructor: ~ProjectBrowser
+		*/
+		virtual ~ProjectBrowser();
+
+		// Fox interface
+		/*
+			Function: create
+		*/
+		void 	create();
+		/*
+			Function: detach
+		*/
+		void 	detach();
+		/*
+			Function: layout
+		*/
+		void 	layout();
+		/*
+			Function: getDefaultWidth
+		*/
+		FXint 	getDefaultWidth();
+		/*
+			Function: getDefautHeight
+		*/
+		FXint 	getDefaultHeight();
+		/*
+			Function: getContentWidth
+		*/
+		FXint 	getContentWidth();
+		/*
+			Function: getContentHeight
+		*/
+		FXint 	getContentHeight();
+		/*
+			Function: recalc
+		*/
+		void 	recalc();
+		/*
+			Function: canFocus
+		*/
+		FXbool 	canFocus() const;
+		/*
+			Function: setFocus
+		*/
+		void 	setFocus();
+		/*
+			Function: killFocus
+		*/
+		void 	killFocus();
+	
+
+		// working operations
+		/*
+			Function: addFile
+
+			adds a file to a project in dir
+		*/
+		void addFile	(FXString project, FXString name, FXString dir, FileType type = TEXT);
+		/*
+			Function: removeFile
+		
+			removes a file from project in dir
+		*/
+		void removeFile	(FXString project, FXString name, FXString dir);
+		/*
+			Function: moveFile
+
+			moves a file in project from olddir to newdir
+		*/
+		void moveFile	(FXString project, FXString name, FXString olddir, FXString newdir);
+		/*
+			Function: renameFile
+
+			renames a file from project in dri from name to newname
+		*/
+		void renameFile	(FXString project, FXString name, FXString newname, FXString dir);
+
+		/*
+			Function: addDir
+		
+			adds a dir of type to project
+		*/
+		void addDir		(FXString project, FXString dirname, DirType type = RESSOURCE);
+		/*
+			Function: removeDir
+
+			removes a dir from project
+		*/
+		void removeDir	(FXString project, FXString dirname);
+		/*
+			Function: renameDir
+
+			renames a dir in project from olddirname to newdirname
+		*/
+		void renameDir	(FXString project, FXString olddirname, FXString newdirname);
+
+		/*
+			Function: addProject
+
+			adds a project to the browser
+		*/
+		void addProject		(FXString name);
+		/*
+			Function: removeProject
+
+			removes a project from the browser
+		*/
+		void removeProject	(FXString name);
+	
+
+		/*
+			Function: getActiveProject
+
+			returns the name of the active project
+		*/
+		FXString getActiveProject();
+
+		// load and save operations
+		/*
+			Function: openProject
+
+			opens project settings from a settingsfile and adds it to the browser
+		*/
+		void openProject(ProjectSettings* settings);
+};
+
+
+
+
+#endif // PROJECTBROWSER_H

Added: trunk/include/ProjectSettings.h
===================================================================
--- trunk/include/ProjectSettings.h	2005-03-10 20:31:09 UTC (rev 28)
+++ trunk/include/ProjectSettings.h	2005-03-11 13:00:42 UTC (rev 29)
@@ -0,0 +1,156 @@
+#ifndef PROJECTSETTINGS_H
+#define PROJECTSETTINGS_H
+
+#include <fx.h>
+
+
+/*
+	Class: ProjectSettings
+
+	Provides abilities to:
+	- Parse and write settings from/to a file
+	- Store and retrieve values depending on key and section
+	- Define default values for a key
+	- Fill missing values with defaults
+	- Replace all values with defaults
+*/
+class ProjectSettings : public FXSettings
+{
+	FXDECLARE(ProjectSettings)
+
+	protected:
+		ProjectSettings() {};
+
+	private:
+		FXString		file;
+		FXSettings*		defaultDict;
+		FXString		name;
+
+	public:
+
+	public:
+
+		/*
+			Constructor: ProjectSettings
+
+			Parameters:
+				filename - File to parse from and write to
+		*/
+		ProjectSettings(const FXString& filename, const FXString& projectname);
+
+		virtual ~ProjectSettings();
+
+		FXString getProjectName() { return name; }
+		/*
+			Function: parse
+
+			Parses the settings file
+
+			- Creates settings file if it doesn't already exist
+			  and writes default values to it
+			- Parses the settings file
+			- Fills missing values with defaults
+		*/
+		void parse();
+
+		void unparse();
+
+		/*
+			Function: defaults
+
+			Method to either fill missing values or to replace all
+			values with defaults
+
+			Parameters:
+				replace - Replace existing values
+		*/
+		void defaults(FXbool replace=true);
+
+		/*
+			Function: write
+
+			Writes settings to the file
+		*/
+		void write();
+
+
+		/*
+			Function: getStringValue
+
+			Returns string value of a key in section "GENERAL"
+		*/
+		const FXchar* getStringValue(const FXString& key);
+
+		/*
+			Function: getStringValue
+
+			Returns string value of a given key in a section
+		*/
+		const FXchar* getStringValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key);
+
+		/*
+			Function: getIntValue
+
+			Returns integer value of a key in section "GENERAL"
+		*/
+		FXint getIntValue(const FXString& key);
+
+		/*
+			Function: getIntValue
+
+			Returns integer value of a key in a section
+		*/
+		FXint getIntValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key);
+
+		/*
+			Function: setStringValue
+
+			Defines a string value for a key in "GENERAL"
+		*/
+		void setStringValue(const FXString& key, const FXString& value);
+
+		/*
+			Function: setStringValue
+
+			Defines a string value for a key in a section
+		*/
+		void setStringValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key, const FXString& value);
+
+		/*
+			Function: setIntValue
+
+			Defines an integer value for a key in "GENERAL"
+		*/
+		void setIntValue(const FXString& key, FXint value);
+
+		/*
+			Function: setIntValue
+
+			Defines an integer value for a key in a section
+		*/
+		void setIntValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key, FXint value);
+		
+		/*
+			Function: setFormatValue
+		*/
+		void setFormatValue(const FXString& key, const FXchar* format, ...);
+		
+		/*
+			Function: setFormatValue
+		*/
+		void setFormatValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key, const FXchar* format, ...);
+		
+		/*
+			Function: getFormatValue
+		*/
+		FXint getFormatValue(const FXString& key, const FXchar* format, ...);
+		
+		/*
+			Function: getFormatValue
+		*/
+		FXint getFormatValue(const FXString& section, const FXString& key, const FXchar* format, ...);
+
+};
+
+
+#endif // PROJECTSETTINGS_H

+		void loadValues();
+
+		/*

+
+			saves the settings to file
+		*/
+		void storeValues();
+
+		/*
+			Function: run
+
+			executes the dialog. Needs the project settings to know which 
+			project to edit.
+		*/
+		void run(ProjectSettings* ProjectSettings);
+};

Added: trunk/include/StringTokenizer.h
===================================================================
--- trunk/include/StringTokenizer.h	2005-03-10 20:31:09 UTC (rev 28)
+++ trunk/include/StringTokenizer.h	2005-03-11 13:00:42 UTC (rev 29)
@@ -0,0 +1,68 @@
+#ifndef STRINGTOKENIZER_H
+#define STRINGTOKENIZER_H
+
+
+#include <fx.h>
+#include <FXArray.h>
+
+
+/*
+	Class: StringTokenizer
+
+	splits a FXString to several Tokens. Provides a seperator, which let's
+	the user choose where to split
+*/
+class StringTokenizer {
+
+	private:
+		FXString	line;
+		FXchar		separator;
+		FXint		pos;
+
+	protected:
+		StringTokenizer(const StringTokenizer&) {}
+
+	public:
+		/*
+			Constructor: StringTokenizer
+
+			reinit() has to be called to initialize the StringTokenizer
+		*/
+		StringTokenizer() {}
+		/*
+			Constructor: StringTokenizer
+
+			creates and initializes the StringTokenizer
+		*/
+		StringTokenizer(FXString line, FXchar separator);
+		/*
+			Destructor: ~StringTokenizer
+		*/
+		~StringTokenizer();
+
+		/*
+			Function: reinit
+		
+			initializes the StringTokenizer after creation.
+			Must be called, if the StringTokenizer is created by the default constructor.
+			May be called to reinit a StrongTokenizer with another String or Separator
+		*/
+		void reinit(FXString line, FXchar separator);
+
+		/*
+			Function: getNextToken
+
+			returns next Token of the splitted String, 
+			returns an empty String, if no Token is left
+		*/
+		FXString			getNextToken();
+		/*
+			Function: getAllTokens
+
+			returns all Tokens in an array.
+			getAllTokens doesn't effect getNextToken
+		*/
+		FXArray<FXString>	getAllTokens();
+};
+
+#endif // STRINGTOKENIZER_H
