Added: trunk/src/FileSystem.cpp
===================================================================
--- trunk/src/FileSystem.cpp	2005-03-15 14:44:15 UTC (rev 34)
+++ trunk/src/FileSystem.cpp	2005-03-15 15:32:18 UTC (rev 35)
@@ -0,0 +1,28 @@
+#include "FileSystem.h"
+
+FXString FS::dirSeparator()
+{
+	#ifdef WIN32
+		return FXString("\\");
+	#else
+		return FXString("/");
+	#endif
+}
+
+FXString FS::hiddenName(const FXString& str)
+{
+	#ifdef WIN32
+		return str;
+	#else
+		return FXString(".") + str;
+	#endif
+}
+
+FXString FS::configFilename(const FXString& str)
+{
+	#ifdef WIN32
+		return str + FXString(".ini");
+	#else
+		return str;
+	#endif
+}

@@ -3,6 +3,7 @@

+#include "FileSystem.h"

From devel at sten-net.de  Tue Mar 15 16:48:16 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Tue, 15 Mar 2005 16:48:16 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] r35 - in trunk: doc/NaturalDocs doc/NaturalDocs/Data
 doc/files doc/index include src
In-Reply-To: <200503151532.j2FFWJZs003322@sheep.berlios.de>
References: <200503151532.j2FFWJZs003322@sheep.berlios.de>
Message-ID: <423703C0.7040001@sten-net.de>

Okay, just to explain the added functions:

dirSeparator():
    should be clear

hiddenName(FXString&):
    On Linux a hidden file is identified by the leading "." in the 
filename. On Windows this is unimportant. This
    function returns either ".filename" or "filename", dependent on 
which platform you are on.

configFilename(FXstring&):
    On Windows, filename extension are useful for associating programs 
with a filetype. On Linux this is mostly
    obsolete due to mime-types (yes?). So this function returns 
"filename.ini" on Windows but "filename" on Linux.

That's all. Those functions at least removed #ifdef WIN32 out of the 
MainWindow constructor. Hehe.

Regards,
Jannis

Hi Eugene.

Eugene Wee schrieb:

> Hi,
>
>>> Don't be to hard to them.
>>> Our two new members, Vlad and Eugene, are present on this list and do
>>> not only read.
>>
> Well, for the most part I'm an observer here.
> I would contribute more if I could (perhaps even join as a developer), 
> but my knowledge of the FOX toolkit is minimal, and my understanding 
> of how the project should progress is rather sketchy.

Yeah, I know it's hard to get through our chaotic minds. Hehe. Well, 
what we're currently doing is to write code for a first test release. 
This will give proof of our ideas and concepts. Then, we will most 
probably have an idea of how to improve our codebase.  For example, the 
TabEditor's API was written down in very short time compared to its 
complexity and thus is not very mature at all.

Contributing to the code without knowing FOX is difficult, of course. 
But perhaps you have some conceptual ideas on certain parts of an IDE in 
general? For example: Which parts should the focus be on? In which 
points do other IDEs fail? Are there useful features you ever wanted to 
have in an IDE? Or: When does an IDE get "blown-up" status?

>
>> That wasn't intended to be criticism. I am really glad both already 
>> wrote something.
>
> Thanks :)
>
> > often
> > it's really hard
> > to say when a certain task is done. Adding a certain feature is ok in
> > this system
> > but defining the percentile status of a whole class is extremely
> > complicated.
> Well, I think that what is important here is not an accurate/precise 
> value, but just a rough gauge based on gut feeling, so that people 
> have an idea what's happening.
>
> After all, who cares if a task is said to be 60% complete when it is 
> actually 59% complete?

Yes, that's how I treat it now. I add a task for everything I'm 
appending to my TODO list. I set a task to 100% when it's basically done 
but let it open if it is still supposed to be enhanced. Once something 
is really done I'm going to close it. The percentage of course is a real 
vague value.

Regards,
Jannis

-
-void ProjectBrowser::setFocus()
-{
-	projectTree->setFocus();
-}
-
-void ProjectBrowser::killFocus()
-{
-	projectTree->killFocus();
-}
-
-
 //////////////////////////////////////////////////
 void ProjectBrowser::addFile(FXString project, FXString name, FXString dir, FileType type)
 {
@@ -228,6 +181,7 @@
 		FXTreeItem* parent = current->getParent();
 		if (parent == NULL)
 			break;
+		current = parent;
 	}
 	return current->getText();
 }
@@ -313,3 +267,50 @@
 	delete strtok;
 }
 
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+FXString ProjectBrowser::getPathname(FXTreeItem* item) 
+{
+	FXString path;
+
+	FXTreeItem* current = item;
+	while (true)
+	{
+		path.prepend(current->getText());
+		path.prepend(FS::dirSeparator());
+		FXTreeItem* parent = current->getParent();
+		if (parent == NULL)
+			break;
+		current = parent;
+	}
+
+	path.prepend(mainWin->settings->getStringValue("baseDir"));
+	return path;
+}
+
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+long ProjectBrowser::onDoubleClick(FXObject* sender, FXSelector sel, void* ptr)
+{
+	FXTRACE((1, "FileBrowser::onDoubleClick()\n"));
+	if (ptr)
+	{
+		FXTreeItem* item = (FXTreeItem*)ptr;
+		if (!projectTree->isItemLeaf(item))
+		{
+	    	if(projectTree->isItemExpanded(item))
+	    	{
+				projectTree->collapseTree(item, TRUE);
+			}
+			else
+			{
+				projectTree->expandTree(item, TRUE);
+			}
+		}
+		else// if (projectTree->isItemLeaf(item))
+		{
+			mainWin->getEditor()->openFile(getPathname(item));
+		}
+	}
+	return 1;
+}

Hi Eugene.

Am Dienstag, den 15.03.2005, 23:51 +0800 schrieb Eugene Wee:
> I would contribute more if I could (perhaps even join as a developer), 
> but my knowledge of the FOX toolkit is minimal, and my understanding of 
> how the project should progress is rather sketchy.
> 
Just thought about this. (Yes, I know I should rather learn for the
exams than hacking or thinking about InDE..... )

What are your skills? 
Do you know about the internals of CVS or SVN? 
What other langueages than C++ do you "speak"?

Tasks, which could be of interest for you, where you do not have to know
all the FOX internals could be:
* add SVN or CVS support
* we work hard, to get InDE working for C++, you could maybe expand InDE
to support other languages.

Syntax highlighting is actually supported for:
language "C++"
language "C"
language "Shell"
language "Pascal"
language "Configure"
language "Python"
language "Ruby"
language "Xml/Html"
language "IDL"
language "C#"
language "Markup"
    filesmatch "*.html,*.xhtml,*.xml,*.sgml,*.php"
language "Make"

I'd like to see support for Java and maybe we need something special for
SCons (wich is basically Python). But that isn't very high priority.

The complete project management is aimed for C++ projects. That also may
fit for C projects.
I only "speak" the following languages: C, C++, Java, Pascal. So,
supporting Java and C projects should be easy for me, but I don't know
anything about Python, Ruby, C#,.... and their structures.

Also it may be of interest to execute programs from Inde and fetch their
output (high priority!). This is needed very soon and could be added as
soon as the SCons file construction is implemented (i will start this
tommorow i hope). So we could add a menu command "build project" wich
basically executes "scons", fetches the output and prints it to a Fox
Window.

May you have other skills, which will be of need and i haven't thought
about.
Just scream, what may be of interest to you ;)

Hope this motivates *g*

Jochen

+#ifndef NEWCLASSDIALOG
+#define NEWCLASSDIALOG
+
+#include <fx.h>
+#include "MainWindow.h"
+
+class NewClassDialog : public FXDialogBox
+{
+	FXDECLARE(NewClassDialog)
+
+	public:
+		FXString		name;
+		FXbool			source;
+		FXbool			header;
+		FXint			sourceDir;
+		FXint			includeDir;
+		FXint			classType;
+

+		FXDataTarget	tgtSource;

+		FXDataTarget	tgtSourceDir;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtIncludeDir;
+		FXDataTarget	tgtClassType;
+
+		MainWindow 		*mw;
+
+	protected:
+		NewClassDialog() {}
+		NewClassDialog(const NewClassDialog&);
+		NewClassDialog& operator=(const NewClassDialog&);
+		
+	public:
+		/*
+			Constructor: NewClassDialog
+		*/
+		NewClassDialog(FXWindow* owner, const FXString& title);
+
+		/*
+			Destructor: ~NewClassDialog
+		*/
+		~NewClassDialog();
+
+		/*
+			Function: create
+		*/
+		virtual void create();
+
+		/*
+			Function: check
+
+			Checks if the user provided us with the needed information
+		*/
+		FXbool check();
+
+		/*
+			Function: run
+
+			executes the dialog. 
+		*/
+		void run(const ProjectSettings* path);
+		
+};

--- trunk/src/NewClassDialog.cpp	2005-03-17 14:24:36 UTC (rev 41)
+++ trunk/src/NewClassDialog.cpp	2005-03-17 16:15:10 UTC (rev 42)
@@ -0,0 +1,134 @@
+/*
+ * InDE - Fast, pragmatic C++ IDE
+ * Copyright (C) 2005 	InDE Development Team
+ *						see AUTHOR file for more information
+ *
+ * This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or
+ * modify it under the terms of the GNU General Public License
+ * as published by the Free Software Foundation; either version 2
+ * of the License, or (at your option) any later version.
+ *
+ * This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
+ * but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
+ * MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
+ * GNU General Public License for more details.
+ *
+ * You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
+ * along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
+ * Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place - Suite 330, Boston, MA  02111-1307, USA.
+ */
+
+#include "NewClassDialog.h"
+#include "DialogTitle.h"
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+// Message map
+FXDEFMAP(NewClassDialog) NewClassDialogMap[] = {
+};
+
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+// Object implementation
+FXIMPLEMENT(NewClassDialog, FXDialogBox, NewClassDialogMap, ARRAYNUMBER(NewClassDialogMap))
+
+
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+// Constructor
+NewClassDialog::NewClassDialog(FXWindow* owner, const FXString& title)
+	:	FXDialogBox(owner, title, DECOR_ALL),
+		tgtName(name),
+		tgtSource(source),
+		tgtHeader(header),
+		tgtSourceDir(sourceDir),
+		tgtIncludeDir(includeDir),
+		tgtClassType(classType),
+		source(1),
+		header(1),
+		sourceDir(0),
+		includeDir(0),
+		classType(0)
+{
+	// get MainWindow
+	FXWindow *mainWindow = getOwner();
+	while (!dynamic_cast<MainWindow*>(mainWindow))
+		mainWindow = mainWindow->getOwner();
+	mw = dynamic_cast<MainWindow*>(mainWindow);
+
+	FXVerticalFrame *frm = new FXVerticalFrame(this, LAYOUT_FILL_X|LAYOUT_FILL_Y);
+	new DialogTitle(frm, "create new class");
+
+	FXHorizontalFrame *hfrm;
+
+	hfrm = new FXHorizontalFrame(frm, LAYOUT_FILL_X);
+	new FXLabel(hfrm, "Class name:");
+	new FXTextField(hfrm, 15, &tgtName, FXDataTarget::ID_VALUE, TEXTFIELD_NORMAL);
+
+	hfrm = new FXHorizontalFrame(frm, LAYOUT_FILL_X);
+	new FXLabel(hfrm, "Create:");
+	new FXCheckButton(hfrm, "Source file", &tgtSource, FXDataTarget::ID_VALUE);
+	new FXCheckButton(hfrm, "Header file", &tgtHeader, FXDataTarget::ID_VALUE);
+	
+	FXGroupBox *gp;
+	FXVerticalFrame *vfrm;
+
+	hfrm = new FXHorizontalFrame(frm, LAYOUT_FILL_X);
+	gp = new FXGroupBox(hfrm, "Dir for source file", FRAME_LINE);
+	vfrm = new FXVerticalFrame(gp, LAYOUT_FILL_X|LAYOUT_FILL_Y);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "source dir", 	&tgtSourceDir, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+0);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "include dir",	&tgtSourceDir, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+1);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "root dir", 	&tgtSourceDir, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+2);
+	gp = new FXGroupBox(hfrm, "Dir for include file", FRAME_LINE);
+	vfrm = new FXVerticalFrame(gp, LAYOUT_FILL_X|LAYOUT_FILL_Y);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "include dir", 	&tgtIncludeDir, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+0);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "source dir", 	&tgtIncludeDir, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+1);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "root dir", 	&tgtIncludeDir, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+2);
+
+	gp = new FXGroupBox(frm, "Class type", FRAME_LINE|LAYOUT_FILL_X);
+	vfrm = new FXVerticalFrame(gp, LAYOUT_FILL_X|LAYOUT_FILL_Y);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "C++ Class", 	&tgtClassType, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+0);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "Python Class", &tgtClassType, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+1);
+	new FXRadioButton(vfrm, "Java Class", 	&tgtClassType, FXDataTarget::ID_OPTION+2);
+
+	hfrm = new FXHorizontalFrame(frm, LAYOUT_FILL_X);
+	new FXButton(hfrm, "&Cancel", NULL, this, FXDialogBox::ID_CANCEL, BUTTON_DEFAULT|LAYOUT_LEFT|FRAME_RAISED|FRAME_THICK, 0, 0, 0, 0, 12, 12, 4, 4);	
+	new FXButton(hfrm, "&Ok", NULL, this, FXDialogBox::ID_ACCEPT, BUTTON_INITIAL|BUTTON_DEFAULT|LAYOUT_RIGHT|FRAME_RAISED|FRAME_THICK, 0, 0, 0, 0, 12, 12, 4, 4);	
+}
+
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+// Destructor
+NewClassDialog::~NewClassDialog()
+{
+}
+
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+// create
+void NewClassDialog::create()
+{
+	FXDialogBox::create();
+}
+
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+// check
+FXbool NewClassDialog::check()
+{
+}
+
+
+//////////////////////////////////////////////////
+// run
+void NewClassDialog::run(const ProjectSettings* path)
+{
+	// execute dialog
+	do
+	{
+		if (!execute(PLACEMENT_OWNER))
+		{
+			return;
+		}
+	} while (!check());
+}
+

@@ -115,13 +121,126 @@
 // check
 FXbool NewClassDialog::check()
 {
+	FXuint errors = 0;
+
+	if (name == "")
+	{
+		++errors;
+		FXMessageBox::error(this, MBOX_OK, "Error", "You should name the class.");
+	}
+
+	settings->parse();
+
+	FXString baseDir = mw->settings->getStringValue("baseDir");
+	baseDir += FS::dirSeparator();
+	baseDir += settings->getProjectName();
+	baseDir += FS::dirSeparator();
+
+	// create source file
+	if (source)
+	{
+		FXString sourcefile = baseDir;
+		FXString sourceName = name;
+		ProjectBrowser::FileType	sourceType;
+		FXString	srcDir;
+		FXString 	srcKey;
+	
+		switch (sourceDir)
+		{
+			case 0:		// source
+				srcDir = settings->getStringValue("DIRECTORY", "sourceDir");
+				sourcefile += srcDir;
+				sourcefile += FS::dirSeparator();
+				srcKey = "source";
+				break;
+			case 1:		// include
+				srcDir = settings->getStringValue("DIRECTORY", "includeDir");
+				sourcefile += srcDir;
+				sourcefile += FS::dirSeparator();
+				srcKey = "include";
+				break;
+			case 2:		// project root
+				srcDir = "";
+				srcKey = "root";
+				break;
+		}
+		if (classType == PROJECT_TYPE_CPP)
+		{
+			sourceName += ".cpp";
+			sourceType = ProjectBrowser::CPP_SOURCE;
+		}
+
+		if (!FXFile::exists(sourcefile+sourceName))
+		{
+			FXFile::createFile(sourcefile+sourceName, 0644);
+			mw->projectBrowser->addFile(settings->getProjectName(), sourceName, srcDir, sourceType);
+			settings->appendStringValue("FILES", srcKey, sourceName);
+		}
+		else
+		{
+			++errors;
+			FXMessageBox::error(this, MBOX_OK, "Error", (sourcefile+sourceName + " already exists.").text());
+		}
+	}
+
+	// create header file
+	if (header)
+	{
+		FXString headerfile = baseDir;
+		FXString headerName = name;
+		ProjectBrowser::FileType	headerType;
+		FXString	incDir;
+		FXString	incKey;
+
+		switch (includeDir)
+		{
+			case 0:		// include
+				incDir = settings->getStringValue("DIRECTORY", "includeDir");
+				headerfile += incDir;
+				headerfile += FS::dirSeparator();
+				incKey = "include";
+				break;
+			case 1:		// source
+				incDir = settings->getStringValue("DIRECTORY", "sourceDir");
+				headerfile += incDir;
+				headerfile += FS::dirSeparator();
+				incKey = "source";
+				break;
+			case 2:		// project root
+				incDir = "";
+				incKey = "root";
+				break;
+		}
+		if (classType == PROJECT_TYPE_CPP)
+		{
+			headerName += ".h";
+			headerType = ProjectBrowser::CPP_HEADER;
+		}
+
+		if (!FXFile::exists(headerfile+headerName))
+		{
+			FXFile::createFile(headerfile+headerName, 0644);
+			mw->projectBrowser->addFile(settings->getProjectName(), headerName, incDir, headerType);
+			settings->appendStringValue("FILES", incKey, headerName);
+		}
+		else
+		{
+			++errors;
+			FXMessageBox::error(this, MBOX_OK, "Error", (headerfile+headerName + " already exists.").text());
+		}
+	}
+
+	settings->write();
+
+	return errors == 0;
 }
 
 
 //////////////////////////////////////////////////
 // run
-void NewClassDialog::run(const ProjectSettings* path)
+void NewClassDialog::run(ProjectSettings* project)
 {
+	settings = project;
 	// execute dialog
 	do
 	{



From devel at sten-net.de  Fri Mar 18 03:47:33 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 03:47:33 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Thoughts and ideas
Message-ID: <423A4145.6030300@sten-net.de>

Hi all.

I observed progress on the project management a little and tested the 
NewClassDialog
recently. Although there are good approaches I'd like to point out some 
weak points regarding
some of our concepts.

The project management lacks of strategy although that's not your fault, 
Jochen. I established
preprocessor defines for the project type and that's been a really bad 
idea. We should
better implement things like that using enum typedefs.

Currently, nearly all actions concerning a project are handled by 
ProjectBrowser. Same with
actions concerning the filesystem. That's ok for now but in the near 
future there are
far more objects which will need to access those actions/methods. The 
class browser or the
CtagHandle for example. This means, instead of using ProjectBrowser for 
all things concerning
the projects we should use some meta-class like objects. I'd call them 
Project and ProjectManager
(a class managing a FXObjectListOf<Project*>, handling stuff like 
getProjectByPath(),
getCurrentProject() and so on).
This would have many advantages. For example, project and class browsers 
could set the current
project independently whenever they get focus or you select a certain 
item in them.
We also could add functions like
     enum ProjectType Project::getProjectType()
to those classes.

Instead of a static list of natively supported licenses we could simply 
provide a dialog
to change the content of the LICENSE file (lets say in the main project 
dir). Depending on files
anywhere in the filesystem always equals chaos. Same applies to the 
syntax file. We simply could
support a syntax file located in the user's InDE directory (copied there 
on first startup), not
allowing the user to select a file located anywhere. A little dialog to 
edit it using an instance
of the Edit class (or a class similar to TabEditor just without tabs) 
would be enough, then.

For the syntax highlighting we will also need a more elegant color 
editing solution than Adie uses.
In Adie, some rule colors of different styles overlap due to similar names.

What we'll probably need some day is a kind of terminal widget. I 
already tried to implement one
using FOX during the last days but it seems to be too complex for the 
moment.

Remember we wanted to release an early version of InDE this weekend? I 
guess we won't. There's
to much reformation needed to get things working.

Yet, I'm proud our project actually evolves and there's still notable 
activity and interest on
the part of the (little team of) developers.

So what will be the next steps?
Jochen, I know you'd like to schedule a release as early as possible but 
if we don't want to
stubmle into chaos we will have to discuss and share exchange views once 
again before (likely)
reorganizing part of the code.

Kind regards,
Jannis


From devel at sten-net.de  Fri Mar 18 05:13:42 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 05:13:42 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Additional thoughts
Message-ID: <423A5576.1010404@sten-net.de>

Hi again.

Some thoughts on ...

Modularization:

I just browsed the Mozilla source code today and learned XUL + XPCOM for 
about ten hours.
While doing so I noticed that it is of great importance to keep your 
code as modular as
possible. Thus, I'm planning to separate the styling part out of 
TabEditor into a new class
with a name like StyleEngine. That way we could - just for example - 
provide syntaxhighlighted
editor widgets anywhere without having to use the TabEditor. Might be 
useful for editing
the syntax file some day or if you want to detach the current document 
from the TabEditor to
a single-document window. That's basically just ideas.


Coding style:

Perhaps we should define some code styling conventions. This would make 
the code more
readable for everyone. Personally, I like the code style they're using 
at Mozilla (w/o emacs line):
    http://www.mozilla.org/hacking/mozilla-style-guide.html#Visual
I'd prefer to use it instead of the mixed code we're using at the moment.


That's it for now. What do you think?

- Jannis


From jochen at cornmania.de  Fri Mar 18 11:58:41 2005
From: jochen at cornmania.de (Jochen Rassler)
Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 11:58:41 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Thoughts and ideas
In-Reply-To: <423A4145.6030300@sten-net.de>
References: <423A4145.6030300@sten-net.de>
Message-ID: <1111143521.1558.37.camel@jogix.sojox>

Hi Jannis.

Am Freitag, den 18.03.2005, 03:47 +0100 schrieb Jannis Pohlmann:
> Hi all.
> 
> I observed progress on the project management a little and tested the 
> NewClassDialog
> recently. Although there are good approaches I'd like to point out some 
> weak points regarding
> some of our concepts.

Thanks for the flowers.
> 
> The project management lacks of strategy although that's not your fault, 
> Jochen. 

It lacks strategy and it's not my fault ???
Thanks in advance!

But maybe you should wait untill things progress. If you've noticed, I
don't code weeks and weeks, before i commit the stuff to svn. So you
only notice the structure that is in the repository, but not what is in
mind. Keep on watching before kicking it.

> I established
> preprocessor defines for the project type and that's been a really bad 
> idea. 

What an ugly design decission.
There is absolutely no need for preprocessor defines! Just let me
improve the code and you will see, what way to go.

BTW, have you ever coded larger apps in Java? There are no preprocessor
defines, because you do not need them, if you use a good design.
Or do you just mean the PROJECT_TYPE_CPP,... which are from you and will
be removed soon?
> We should
> better implement things like that using enum typedefs.

That's what is planned.
> 
> Currently, nearly all actions concerning a project are handled by 
> ProjectBrowser. Same with
> actions concerning the filesystem. That's ok for now but in the near 
> future there are
> far more objects which will need to access those actions/methods. The 
> class browser or the
> CtagHandle for example. 

Well, the project browser implements only those methods, which
correspond to the project browser. Except the opening of a file, but
this seems to be another discussion. For those things we can start a new
thread to discuss.

Also, if it is needed to give things a better structure or way to
access, while implementing new features, THIS is the time to build this
structure, not any hour earlier!

> This means, instead of using ProjectBrowser for 
> all things concerning
> the projects we should use some meta-class like objects. I'd call them 
> Project and ProjectManager
> (a class managing a FXObjectListOf<Project*>, handling stuff like 
> getProjectByPath(),
> getCurrentProject() and so on).
> This would have many advantages. For example, project and class browsers 
> could set the current
> project independently whenever they get focus or you select a certain 
> item in them.

I remember you wouldn't even support several projects at once. What
should those classes do?

> We also could add functions like
>      enum ProjectType Project::getProjectType()
> to those classes.
Why? A project may be a Java project, but uses several C++ classes or C
code to access system calls..... 
Having such a static project setting would kick out the need for SCons.
> 
> Instead of a static list of natively supported licenses we could simply 
> provide a dialog
> to change the content of the LICENSE file (lets say in the main project 
> dir). Depending on files
> anywhere in the filesystem always equals chaos. 

You don't know how it will be implemented. So please don't argue about
that before you know how things will be done.
The only dependency to the file system occurs, if the user chooses a non
supported (non-standard) license.
Also wait and see before accusing it!

> Same applies to the 
> syntax file. We simply could
> support a syntax file located in the user's InDE directory (copied there 
> on first startup), not
> allowing the user to select a file located anywhere. A little dialog to 
> edit it using an instance
> of the Edit class (or a class similar to TabEditor just without tabs) 
> would be enough, then.

That's right, but not my job.
> 
> For the syntax highlighting we will also need a more elegant color 
> editing solution than Adie uses.
> In Adie, some rule colors of different styles overlap due to similar names.

That's what i always said. But if you remember, we decided not to change
this before other basic things are implemented and/or improved.
For example, the editor is very unstable. Why not first improve the
editor code base to eliminate all those ugly seg faults? InDE is
absolutly useless as long the editor doesn't work properly!

> 
> What we'll probably need some day is a kind of terminal widget. I 
> already tried to implement one
> using FOX during the last days but it seems to be too complex for the 
> moment.

You told me, you had written some code, that executes external commands
and fetches the output. Maybe you'll give me that code, i will see what
can be done to this.

And one day means, that it is one day needed. No need to get a headache
by now!
> 
> Remember we wanted to release an early version of InDE this weekend? I 
> guess we won't. There's
> to much reformation needed to get things working.

Hey, slowly!
If you mean a reformation like the last, simply forget it! 
You removed several classes, deleted code,.....
I had two days work to get all functionality back to InDE and back to
work. If you start a new reformation such this one, I'd need more time.
And i hate to implement everything twice. 
Maybe you should read "Software entwickeln mit eXtreme Programming" von
Lippert, Roock, Wolf. I really recomend that book. And for you
especially the parts of Refactoring.

We can discuss about code improvements and than do it step by step. But
i will not support this, if the discussion or improvement is done with
the sledge hammer, like this mail or the last restructuring!

And, I still believe, it's best to get things actually working,
releasing a snapshot and working on new features and improvements of old
features.

It looks like every time you think about a new feature which could be
added any time, you find the InDE code not fitting anymore and rewriting
the complete code every time.
This isn't only ineffective, but also senseless and short viewed.
> 
> Yet, I'm proud our project actually evolves and there's still notable 
> activity and interest on
> the part of the (little team of) developers.

Keep it so!
> 
> So what will be the next steps?
> Jochen, I know you'd like to schedule a release as early as possible but 
> if we don't want to
> stubmle into chaos we will have to discuss and share exchange views once 
> again before (likely)
> reorganizing part of the code.

If you don't want to end in chaos, follow a clear line and don't loose
in senseless reorganizations every two weeks.
Sure, little reorganizations are needed all times, but little. I don't
support a rewrite every two weeks.

And, let me do the restructuring of my code! I don't want to rewrite it
every time!

I still keep our schedule in mind!

Jochen

> code as modular as

> TabEditor into a new class

> editor widgets anywhere without having to use the TabEditor. Might be 
> useful for editing
> the syntax file some day or if you want to detach the current document

>Thanks in advance!
>
InDE evolves, that's clear. It's only that I noticed parts of our code 
aren't very well
thought-out and thus, there are many sources of error. I wanted to introduce
new ideas, not an immediate reorganization of the code.

>
>But maybe you should wait untill things progress. If you've noticed, I
>don't code weeks and weeks, before i commit the stuff to svn. So you
>only notice the structure that is in the repository, but not what is in
>mind. Keep on watching before kicking it.
>
>
>>I established
>>preprocessor defines for the project type and that's been a really bad 
>>idea. 
>>
>
>What an ugly design decission.
>There is absolutely no need for preprocessor defines! Just let me
>improve the code and you will see, what way to go.
>
Yes, I know. Replacing them with something better fortunately won't be 
much work.

>
>BTW, have you ever coded larger apps in Java? There are no preprocessor
>defines, because you do not need them, if you use a good design.
>Or do you just mean the PROJECT_TYPE_CPP,... which are from you and will
>be removed soon?
>
>>We should
>>better implement things like that using enum typedefs.
>>
>
>That's what is planned.
>
>>Currently, nearly all actions concerning a project are handled by 
>>ProjectBrowser. Same with
>>actions concerning the filesystem. That's ok for now but in the near 
>>future there are
>>far more objects which will need to access those actions/methods. The 
>>class browser or the
>>CtagHandle for example. 
>>
>
>Well, the project browser implements only those methods, which
>correspond to the project browser. Except the opening of a file, but
>this seems to be another discussion. For those things we can start a new
>thread to discuss.
>
It currently also is responsible for opening a project and that will 
lead into conflicts
with - for example - the class browser. A kind of ProjectManager class 
with a list of
projects located in MainWindow simply would be better.

>
>Also, if it is needed to give things a better structure or way to
>access, while implementing new features, THIS is the time to build this
>structure, not any hour earlier!
>
>>This means, instead of using ProjectBrowser for 
>>all things concerning
>>the projects we should use some meta-class like objects. I'd call them 
>>Project and ProjectManager
>>(a class managing a FXObjectListOf<Project*>, handling stuff like 
>>getProjectByPath(),
>>getCurrentProject() and so on).
>>This would have many advantages. For example, project and class browsers 
>>could set the current
>>project independently whenever they get focus or you select a certain 
>>item in them.
>>
>
>I remember you wouldn't even support several projects at once. What
>should those classes do?
>
Several projects would be no problem (that's what a ProjectManager would 
be responsible
for - handling projects). The Project class could be seen as a layer 
over ProjectSettings,
providing useful things like a project directory/files iterator class 
and things like that. I read
a lot about design patterns recently. That could be useful.

>
>>We also could add functions like
>>     enum ProjectType Project::getProjectType()
>>to those classes.
>>
>Why? A project may be a Java project, but uses several C++ classes or C
>code to access system calls..... 
>Having such a static project setting would kick out the need for SCons.
>
The projectType must not be used as a static setting - but it could (yet 
must not) be
used for the File => New ... => Class. I'm thinking of a projectType 
dependent
Factory for the class creation, support several languages (each with 
their own
builder). Practical design patterns once again.

>>Instead of a static list of natively supported licenses we could simply 
>>provide a dialog
>>to change the content of the LICENSE file (lets say in the main project 
>>dir). Depending on files
>>anywhere in the filesystem always equals chaos. 
>>
>
>You don't know how it will be implemented. So please don't argue about
>that before you know how things will be done.
>The only dependency to the file system occurs, if the user chooses a non
>supported (non-standard) license.
>Also wait and see before accusing it!
>
No need to get angry. I'm not going to change anything of the code until 
I've
seen something more complete. But a single LICENSE file where you can
paste text into using a dialog doesn't require much work and a simple check
if the file exists when creating a class file should be no problem either.

If you think of being able to provide something easier and user friendly 
- good!

>
>>Same applies to the 
>>syntax file. We simply could
>>support a syntax file located in the user's InDE directory (copied there 
>>on first startup), not

>absolutly useless as long the editor doesn't work properly!

Yes, tri-state return values for saveDocument() are coming. That's the 
most disturbing

>>What we'll probably need some day is a kind of terminal widget. I 
>>already tried to implement one
>>using FOX during the last days but it seems to be too complex for the

That wasn't C++. It was written in Ruby. A terminal still is something 
completely
different as it includes getting a TTY device as well as writing and 
reading from it.

>
>And one day means, that it is one day needed. No need to get a headache
>by now!

No, I was intended as a short sidenote, nothing more.

>>Remember we wanted to release an early version of InDE this weekend? I 
>>guess we won't. There's
>>to much reformation needed to get things working.

>especially the parts of Refactoring.

Maybe I should. But you have to think about at least two things: An IDE 
is not a tiny
program, instead it's complex. And we should have had more discussions about
it before writing code. It's true that you can't think of everything and 
write
a program from the scratch without problems - but one should at least try to
develop concepts before starting. That's what I learn with every day I 
deal with
InDE.

Maybe we're not sophisticated programmes yet, so we have to realize that
development sometimes leads to a dead end where you have to reconsider
things. If we're honest, there is not much code yet. Most parts are attempts
which will be rewritten - maybe from the scratch - either way.

InDE is not an application written down in a month or two. I'm not afraid
of rewriting core stuff that will be important for nearly everything in the
near future if it makes the software more sophisticated.

>
>We can discuss about code improvements and than do it step by step. But
>i will not support this, if the discussion or improvement is done with
>the sledge hammer, like this mail or the last restructuring!

It's not intended to be a "sledge hammer". It's just brainstorming and 
writing
down experiences. Sure we could do everything step by step but that exactly
is the problem. If you add something like the ProjectManager (and 
Project) as
I suggested, more things have to be reviewed. If we had a comfortable 
project
directory/files iterator the listing in the ProjectBrowser would be much 
easier.

The only problem is, those ideas require a complete review of InDE. I 
will do
that anyway (and make it a folder InDE-rev on my harddisk) but I won't 
apply
the code to the official InDE until you agree on it.

>
>And, I still believe, it's best to get things actually working,
>releasing a snapshot and working on new features and improvements of old
>features.

Features aren't a problem, it's the way they're implemented currently. 
That's not
your fault, as project leader I had to kick development into the right 
direction but
unfortunately I didn't. I'm not that experienced yet.

>
>It looks like every time you think about a new feature which could be

for filling the project browser with the contents (files) of the
project.
Maybe i've chosen not the best name for that function, but it loads the
contents from the view of the project browser, but not the complete
project.
>

> be responsible

and delegates to it's classes, not like now, were the accessing code has
to be implemented in MainWindow. But this leads to a small refactoring,
which can be done while reviewing the code.

> a program from the scratch without problems - but one should at least try to

> deal with
> InDE.

Ok, to express it in other words:
let us finish the work that is in progress and not yet ready (e.g.
stability of the editor, SCons constructing, some more methods for
adding, deleting,... files to the project). If all open points work
well, let us release this stuff and discuss about the problems we have
with this design, what may lead to problems, what can be done for better
modularization, which code should be moved to another abstraction
layer,....
If we do so, we get several benefits:
* users provide us with bugreports, so we get feedback on problems, we
might not have seen yet.
* we know, how we planned some things to implement
* we know, what will come next and what problems may occure for this (we
can not plan for features comming in years....)
* ...

> 
> Maybe we're not sophisticated programmes yet, so we have to realize that
> development sometimes leads to a dead end where you have to reconsider
> things. If we're honest, there is not much code yet. Most parts are attempts
> which will be rewritten - maybe from the scratch - either way.

I do not see a dead end alley at the moment.

Including the above, InDE will be complex, so trying to design it once
will lead to dead ends. So, we have to do it step by step, and not
always try to rewrite it at once, no matter how much code exists. You
will continue this approach your life long and don't get any progress,
but you need to.
> 
> InDE is not an application written down in a month or two. I'm not afraid
> of rewriting core stuff that will be important for nearly everything in the
> near future if it makes the software more sophisticated.

see above.
Do it step by step, and as i mentioned in several mails before, do it
when it's needed, and only those parts which need to be rewritten and
not the whole stuff at once. Also everything is new, it hasn't to be
better, only because it'sd new!
> 
> >
> It's not intended to be a "sledge hammer". It's just brainstorming and

> 
I don't mind to throw code away if it's ugly or morbid.
But if that code is the base of thoughts and will be improved, you don't
have to throw it away, before any improvement could have been done to
it. That's why i'm crying!

Jochen

>>Maybe I should. But you have to think about at least two things: An IDE

>>it before writing code. It's true that you can't think of everything and 
>>write
>>a program from the scratch without problems - but one should at least try to
>>develop concepts before starting. That's what I learn with every day I 
>>deal with
>>InDE.

>
>Ok, to express it in other words:
>let us finish the work that is in progress and not yet ready (e.g.
>stability of the editor, SCons constructing, some more methods for
>adding, deleting,... files to the project). If all open points work
>well, let us release this stuff and discuss about the problems we have
>with this design, what may lead to problems, what can be done for better
>modularization, which code should be moved to another abstraction
>layer,....
>If we do so, we get several benefits:
>* users provide us with bugreports, so we get feedback on problems, we
>might not have seen yet.
>* we know, how we planned some things to implement
>* we know, what will come next and what problems may occure for this (we
>can not plan for features comming in years....)
>* ...
>  
>
ACK.

>  
>
>>Maybe we're not sophisticated programmes yet, so we have to realize that
>>development sometimes leads to a dead end where you have to reconsider
>>things. If we're honest, there is not much code yet. Most parts are attempts
>>which will be rewritten - maybe from the scratch - either way.
>>    
>>
>
>I do not see a dead end alley at the moment.
>
>Including the above, InDE will be complex, so trying to design it once
>will lead to dead ends. So, we have to do it step by step, and not
>always try to rewrite it at once, no matter how much code exists. You
>will continue this approach your life long and don't get any progress,
>but you need to.
>  
>
There are two ways: Reformating the base until they're good enough to 
build everything
else upon - or writing the base once and optimizing it step by step 
while implementing
everything else upon it. The latter seems odd to me. But I'll wait with 
my criticism until
the first test release is out.

>>InDE is not an application written down in a month or two. I'm not afraid
>>of rewriting core stuff that will be important for nearly everything in the
>>near future if it makes the software more sophisticated.
>>    
>>
>You introduced the sledge hammer!
>Surely, you have to do it step by step, except you want to implement the
>same stuff for years without any progress.
>  
>
I think it's better to have a base you can rely on than to have a base 
you have
to change whenever you realize it isn't yet ready for a new feature. To 
a certain
degree, both require changes from time to time - that's for sure - but 
my simple
criticism is that the current base is not yet ready for even the 
low-level features.

We can't handle projects by simply adding a ProjectSettings object to 
GUI widgets.
We need something better. OK, you seem to be up to something - then I'll 
give
you enough time to develop your stuff.

>Yes, you are the king!
>Also the wrong way!
>  
>
I always loved self-criticism - that's another one of my bad habbits. 
Hehe, really.

Regards,
Jannis

changes?

parts as they need to and not only sometimes the whole thing at once.

the code base doesn't fit instead of hacking without thinking and then
standing in front of a big mountain and start wondering where to start.

to be best to have all the basics. So we can estimate where the class
will evolve to.

changes
to the things relying on it. I can't imagine the work that would be 
necessary to
reorganize codebase with, lets say 100k lines of code. The advantage of
refacturing now would be that there aren't that much components written yet.
But that's just how I see things.

>I intent to always think about the code base and do little changes, if

Sounds good actually. I have ideas about that. As already mentioned I 
could imagine
a kind of meta information object for each project which wraps the 
information it
fetches from its ProjectSettings member into something useable for other 
components.
Like e.g. a project directory/file iterator class which could be used in 
the project browser
- or a default <LanguageOfChoice>ClassBuilder object which is factorized 
dependent on the
projectType. those ClassBuilder (e.g. CppClassBuilder) could be used to 
store and validate
information entered into the NewClassDialog. That's one of those things 
for the future which I'm
currently working on. Intelligent components which aren't easy to 
integrate into the current
codebase without much changes.

Regards,
Jannis

>Hi Jannis.
>
>Am Freitag, den 18.03.2005, 19:27 +0100 schrieb Jannis Pohlmann:
>  
>
>>Sounds good actually. I have ideas about that. As already mentioned I 
>>could imagine
>>a kind of meta information object for each project which wraps the 
>>information it
>>fetches from its ProjectSettings member into something useable for other 
>>components.
>>Like e.g. a project directory/file iterator class which could be used in 
>>the project browser
>>- or a default <LanguageOfChoice>ClassBuilder object which is factorized 
>>dependent on the
>>projectType. those ClassBuilder (e.g. CppClassBuilder) could be used to 
>>store and validate
>>information entered into the NewClassDialog. That's one of those things 
>>for the future which I'm
>>currently working on. Intelligent components which aren't easy to 
>>integrate into the current
>>codebase without much changes.
>>

>Do you want to write a code generator?
>  
>
Yes, I had that in mind. To be honest, I've already written it. Hehe.

An iterator class for files in the project would be great. I don't think 
that's oversized.
This way the project meta class would have to wrap the files listed in 
project.inde into
a simple struct/class structure. Afterwards it would be easy to write an 
iterator for that.

That's just an idea but could be useful for the project browser for example.

Besides I'm somewhat thinking of separating InDE into the program itself 
and
a "InDE Foundation Library". This means we would add all these classes 
we need
into a library and then use them in InDE itself. The program's code 
itself was much
shorter, then - and other developers could use the library to build 
editors etc.

That would too much for the first release, but thereafter ... - what do 
you think?

Regards,
Jannis

The problem most probably is in one of the methods of TabEditor that 
determine
which document has changed (inserted, replaced, deleted) and then try to 
restyle
it. Restyling seems to be ok, but sometimes a wrong document is 
determined and
then the app crashes. I'm working on it.

Bugfix (TabEditor): Restyling a document failed when there were more than one documents opened

@@ -219,7 +219,12 @@
 
 		if (!FXFile::exists(headerfile+headerName))
 		{
+			FXTRACE((1, "Creating header file '%s'...\n", FXString(headerfile+headerName).text()));
 			FXFile::createFile(headerfile+headerName, 0644);
+			if (FXFile::exists(headerfile+headerName))
+			{
+				FXTRACE((1, "... done.\n"));
+			}
 			mw->projectBrowser->addFile(settings->getProjectName(), headerName, incDir, headerType);
 			settings->appendStringValue("FILES", incKey, headerName);
 		}

 long TabEditor::onTextInserted(FXObject* sender, FXSelector, void* ptr)

+	FXuint index = indexOfChild(((Edit*)sender)->getParent()->getParent()) / 2;
 	((Edit*)sender)->setModified();

 	restyleDocument(index, change->pos,change->ndel,change->nins);

 {
 	FXTRACE((1, "TabEditor::onTextReplaced()\n"));

+	FXuint index = indexOfChild(((Edit*)sender)->getParent()->getParent()) / 2;
 	((Edit*)sender)->setModified();
 	const FXTextChange* change = (const FXTextChange*)ptr;
 	restyleDocument(index, change->pos,change->ndel,change->nins);
@@ -515,7 +515,7 @@

 {

+	FXuint index = indexOfChild(((Edit*)sender)->getParent()->getParent()) / 2;

 	const FXTextChange* change = (const FXTextChange*)ptr;

From devel at sten-net.de  Sat Mar 19 20:19:01 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 20:19:01 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Additional thoughts
In-Reply-To: <1111169517.1558.84.camel@jogix.sojox>
References: <423A5576.1010404@sten-net.de>	 <1111143676.1558.40.camel@jogix.sojox>  <423ACCFE.1090305@sten-net.de> <1111169517.1558.84.camel@jogix.sojox>
Message-ID: <423C7B25.8020508@sten-net.de>

Jochen Rassler schrieb:

>>>I am a believer in coding conventions and normally follow the sun coding
>>>conventions...
>>> 
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>Can I find an overview over them anywhere in the internet?
>>    
>>
>http://java.sun.com/docs/codeconv/
>  
>
Well, they're not that different from the guidelines of the Mozilla 
foundation. But I'd like
to mark variables with a certain prefix so that everyone is able to see 
where they come
from (examples: mProjects - member variable, gStyles - global variable9 
and what their
purpose is. That's not covered by the Java conventions, I think. Often 
authors of such
directives advise you not to use things like prefixes but it's a good 
way to make things
much clearer in my opinion.

I will write a guideline and ask you to review and share your opinion 
about it.

Regards,
Jannis


From devel at sten-net.de  Sun Mar 20 09:51:12 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Sun, 20 Mar 2005 09:51:12 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Thoughts and ideas
In-Reply-To: <423C6C78.2010902@sten-net.de>
References: <423A4145.6030300@sten-net.de>	 <1111143521.1558.37.camel@jogix.sojox>  <423ACC0B.1060208@sten-net.de>	 <1111154203.1558.70.camel@jogix.sojox>  <423AE802.5090806@sten-net.de>	 <1111169375.1558.81.camel@jogix.sojox>  <423B1DAB.8040505@sten-net.de> <1111229736.1542.0.camel@jogix.sojox> <423C6C78.2010902@sten-net.de>
Message-ID: <423D3980.5080704@sten-net.de>

Hi.

>> Do you want to write a code generator?
>>  
>>
> Yes, I had that in mind. To be honest, I've already written it. Hehe.


I've worked on it again and although it's on my TODO list for the things 
to come after
the initial test release, I think we can already use it - if you agree.

It is relatively simple:

There is a struct "MethodParam" with two members: name and type of the 
parameter
(both FXString). Then, there is a class "ClassMethod" to which you can 
apply parameters,
modifiers (const, virtual and so on), access level (public, private, 
...) and return type.
That's all (mostly) language independent. It at least work for Java, 
Ruby, Python,
C++ and Delphi/Pascal.

Next there is a abstract class "ClassBuilder". It provides basic methods 
for adding
methods to the class, to set the class name. But most important are the 
virtual methods
it has, like validating, rendering and writing methods. These have to be 
overloaded by
the language-specific classes.

Finally, we've got a subclass of "ClassBuilder" for each language (e.g. 
CppClassBuilder or
RubyClassBuilder). We need to subclass "ClassBuilder" in order to have 
the same
API for every language ClassBuilder so that we later can use something 
like this:

ClassBuilder* builder;
switch (dialog.Language()) {
    case Java:
       builder = new JavaClassBuilder(dialog.ClassName());
       break;
    case Ruby:
       builder = new RubyClassBuilder(dialog.ClassName());
       break;
    default:
       builder = new CppClassBuilder(dialog.ClassName());
}
if (builder->IsValid()) {
    builder->Finalize();

    // C++ differs from any other language due to its separation of
    // declaration and implementation so we have to create two
    // files instead of one:

    if (builder->Language() == Cpp) {
       builder->write(builder->Name() + ".h", builder->Name() + ".cpp");
    } else {
       builder->write(builder->Name() + builder->Language()->Extension());
    }
}

This would be (nearly) everything we needed to write in order to create 
valid sourcecode for
any OO language.
Of course, there is no function "IsValid". Instead, there are few more 
functions for the validation
so that we are able to react on invalid class names, an invalid method 
and so on individually.

Those classes depend on nothing of the current sourcecode and thus would 
integrate fine
into it. This would make the "Create Class" command possible in the test 
release already.

What do you think, Jochen?

- Jannis


From devel at sten-net.de  Sun Mar 20 09:58:22 2005
From: devel at sten-net.de (Jannis Pohlmann)
Date: Sun, 20 Mar 2005 09:58:22 +0100
Subject: [InDE-devel] Thoughts and ideas
In-Reply-To: <423D3980.5080704@sten-net.de>
References: <423A4145.6030300@sten-net.de>	 <1111143521.1558.37.camel@jogix.sojox>  <423ACC0B.1060208@sten-net.de>	 <1111154203.1558.70.camel@jogix.sojox>  <423AE802.5090806@sten-net.de>	 <1111169375.1558.81.camel@jogix.sojox>  <423B1DAB.8040505@sten-net.de> <1111229736.1542.0.camel@jogix.sojox> <423C6C78.2010902@sten-net.de> <423D3980.5080704@sten-net.de>
Message-ID: <423D3B2E.2000507@sten-net.de>

I forgot to mention that I'm writing classes for the languages itself at 
the moment.

Those derive from an abstract class "Language" and have mostly static 
methods for
validation the names of types, parameters, functions, classes and 
modifiers as well
as some methods for retrieving the default file extension for that 
language and so on
and so on ...

This means: Every programming language we want to support require two 
classes
to be written: <Insert Language alias here>ClassBuilder and
<Insert Language alias here>Language. Examples would be:
    - CppClassBuilder, CppLanguage
    - RubyClassBuilder, RubyLanguage
    - JavaClassBuilder, JavaLanguage

Just to make my last mail complete.

- Jannis
